pros:
True experts within most technical domains
Microsoft and Accenture relationships result in projects at household names
Rigorous training and on-boarding process topped only by a rigorous delivery methodology.  You learn *how* to work to guarantee results. This makes you extremely marketable.

Healthcare and 401k are fine.  They work as they're supposed to.  The technology budget they give you sounds cool up front, until you realize it's just withheld salary.  Anything you expense is taxed as salary, not as a business expense.  So, essentially, a piece of your salary is held ransom unless you spend it on something the company approves of.  Then you pay taxes on it.
cons:
Internally, no one even pretends there is work/life balance.  If you're under a certain level, kiss your evenings goodbye.  Your new best friends are offshore. This is a lifestyle, not a job.

Regardless of the success of your project or happiness of your client, your performance is evaluated based on the perceptions of others and your willingness to bow to process that doesn't further either a) the success of your project or b) the happiness of your client.  If you don't fall in line, you don't move up.

Salary is known to be short of market standards, however this is acceptable because, unless you plan on being a lifer at Avanade, you'll find an opportunity to leave for a significant (25%+) raise.  I found the more senior folks I worked with, the less creative and fun the role became.  

There's even a push to make the on-shore folks just act as champions of requirement documentation and letting offshore do all the fun parts.

pros:
Great perks including health insurance, gadget allowance and 5 days personal leave
Access to latest tech (inhouse)
cons:
“The only choice you have is whether you choose to work in exchange for a salary.” – Avanade HR, 2019

Chargeability comes above all else; employees are just a number and their individual career aspirations ultimately don’t matter. 

Negative feedback toward project experiences is a recurring theme in employee engagement feedback. 

Consultants have almost no say in where they are assigned. They can be thrown into any role regardless of whether they are skilled, interested, or looking to grow/gain new skills. Non-technical people writing PowerShell scripts and data scientists pigeonholed in their previous roles. Me, well I explicitly asked not to do a specific type of role, so guess what I did back-to-back?

You can’t be naïve thinking you can just roll off when you get bored. In one project, I worked with the same screens for years and I had to beg for mercy to escape. It’s not uncommon to find Avanade consultants who have remained in the same client for 3 years, 5 years or even more.
 
IT projects can be ground-breaking and innovative. They can have a genuine social impact. This just wasn’t my experience across projects.

It’s near impossible to get promoted nowadays and the bar is being raised higher each year. Being exceptional in your day job isn’t enough; it’s ultra-competitive and only those who take on significant extracurricular activities have any chance to succeed. I write from personal experience: I was one of the successful ones.

pros: The company offers good perks and benefits giving the new grads a good feeling of importance as they enter to the consulting world
cons:
If you are seasoned consultant you will be shocked from your first project.  I did several projects and every time I was hoping the other senior consultants will show some professionalism in planning and execution but I get disappointed every single time. 

The culture followed is to please the client and they achieve that by saying yes to every single request regardless of the feasibility which leads to over promising and hardship on delivery.  
This practice is followed to keep existing clients and get new clients which works for a while but I've seen older clients slipping away after discovering that they were over promised.  

Promotion is based how much can you sell to the client and how many resources you can assign to a project but they don't consider the long term vision of what value they provided to the client. 

The company also survives on Accenture, yet they have a lot to learn from Accenture in terms of process and quality.  

The 15000+ employees they claim they have are actually Accenture resources who are tagged for Avanade on off-shore centers. 
 
In short, the company does a good job on marketing and advertising its brand(following Accenture model) which gives the feeling that it's a great organization to work for while it lacks experience on management and delivery.  It's not a bad place to start a career but if you are intermediate to senior IT professional you will know that you could do better somewhere else.

Each employee is assigned a career manager who acts as a mentor, supervisor and advocate.
cons: Its very difficult to get the company to send you for training courses.  Pay scale is a bit below market value.  Staff is expected to work overtime without compensation.  Significant levels of dissatisfaction in role assignments and growth opportunities which have resulted in high attrition rates.  Management appears to take little interest in staff job satisfaction.  The poor medical coverage can lead to significant cost to employees in deducatables and copays.  To get promoted, your career manager (immediate supervisor) need to push for your promotion.  Usually this works well.  However, when a career manager is overworked, apathetic, or the attrition rate is high and a staff member is assigned a new career manager every 3 months, it becomes very difficult to get a promotion.

If you're on a project that you're not thrilled to be on, then you'll find yourself in a tricky situation where if you speak up about it, it might negatively affect your performance reviews, but if you don't speak up, then you might find yourself going down a path that you don't want to be on. review_title: Great place for technology and experience, but leadership is in the clouds and information sharing/collaboration is poor

A great place to start a tech career and become a well rounded person with a focus on technology. Work with the newest Microsoft technologies, and get your certifications on the house. Please customers and managers, show ambition for technology and working with people, and please customers and managers and you can move very quickly.
cons: Avanade has trouble deciding if it cares more about its consultants or its customers. Lots of movement and reorganization at the leadership level, with constant reminders to the rank-and-file that it "doesn't change your day job", plus heavy focus on customers leaves many consultants feeling disconnected from the organization. Talks the talk when it comes to collaboration and sharing between employees, but doesn't walk the walk - the community discussion groups (supported purely by the goodwill of the many smart consultants) are a good resource but don't expect an environment where you can work on and contribute meaningful assets unless you can turn them into money trees immediately. Swears up and down that they are not becoming Accenture, which appears less and less true every day.

They offer many rescources to teach yourself programming, but on top of already working a 40+ hour work week and travelling, it is very hard to motivate yourself to study on the weekends, especially if programming doesn't come naturally.  I expected more of a requirements gathering and solution proposal opportunity, but was really hired to be a customer facing programmer/coder.

review_title: Great for work-life balance, not exactly a leading digital innovator
pros:
- Most projects are pretty respectful for work-life balance, I rarely worked over 50 hours per week even when traveling
- The company pays for all certifications (at least to my knowledge) and is very supportive of employees getting certifications
- Career Advisors can be fantastic, but that is dependent on the advisor that you get
- You are largely in charge of your career, it seems like the people that get promoted are the ones that go above-and-beyond
cons:
- As the title says, Avanade pitches itself as a leading digital innovator. When it comes to consulting firms, probably. When it comes to an actual leading digital innovator, I'd say they're at least 3 years behind
- While promotions are largely merit-based, there are some bureaucratic  requirements that can hold you back, especially if you get hired in young and well-below what you should've been brought in at
- If you don't like to travel 4 days a week, beware! 
- Most projects here are no cutting edge, especially if you're in the analytics space. Get used to working on Power BI dashboards and basic on-prem -> cloud transformations

pros: Get involved in big project (Projects from Accenture most of times)
cons:
Very limited promotion opportunity
Low pay
high onbench rate for GDN
No one(Leaders) cares new Microsoft technologies

review_title: One of the best work experience I have ever had
pros: You will be in one of the best work environments you can be
cons: The salaries are very low

review_title: Great company to work for, be prepared to work hard
pros:
Avanade is a great company to work for and they really do value and look after their people. The office locations are great but you also have the flexibility to work from home and manage your own diary depending on the client.

There are always competitions, incentives, and programmes running on celebrating and promoting inclusion, diversity, and mental health to name a few.

The company focusses hugely on training and runs their own internal courses locally, regionally, and globally as well as providing plenty of Microsoft exam vouchers to gain certifications.

Everyone is super supportive and it's a close family to work with. The world is your oyster to progress, although the promotion process is fairly cumbersome and only runs twice a year though this is being changed I believe.

The pay and benefits are good and there's plenty to take advantage of in Avanade and Accenture.
cons:
There's a huge focus on one thing; chargeability. Only two days of onboarding and then you're left to fend for yourself to get on a project and become chargeable - a quite stressful time when everything is new and you hardly know anyone.

There's a certain stigma attached to being 'on the bench' but once you're on a project things start to calm down.

A lot of work comes from Accenture which have bigger projects and customers but can take away from Avanade's close family bond.

pros: vacation, work life balance, social conscience
cons: less pay than other consulting firms

review_title: Good place to work for Microsoft technologists
pros:
Excellent opportunity to learn new technologies and grow professionally.
Some of the smartest bunch of technical people.
Company invests a lot of money and time in training employees on Microsoft technologies and soft skills -- in-person, virtual instructor led, self-paced, third party, you name it. 
Awesome training group, much better than most Microsoft technology companies. 
Excellent infrastructure for knowledge sharing, networking and beta testing of new Microsoft technologies.
Great benefits.
Opportunity to travel all over the US. Depending on whether travel fits your life style, this could be a minus.
cons:
Top heavy -- Way too many managers in every service line. This creates a lot of clumsy processes and also hampers career growth for everyone else.
Depending on whether you are in consulting or ATS service line, noticeable difference in organizational respect and in benefits.
Career Manger role is mostly a formality; your manager won't care as long as your billing hours are high and your project manager did not give you bad rating. They lack organizational maturity and/or backbone to resolve your issues. 
Promotional opportunity depends on how well you click with your regional and service line leadership. 
Avanade delivery managers try to imitate Accenture PMs. I don't understand why every project needs clones. Most of these managers don't seem to care about the team's wants and needs and behave like slave masters. They are on the project mainly because of their chargeability; not to add value.
They will nickel and dime you on salary negotiations.

review_title: Disappointing - potential to be much, much better
pros:
Some great minds and great people work here!
Opportunity to find and meet (virtually) with Avanade employees from around the globe thanks to Avanade intranet and active Avanade communities. 
Good examples of global collaboration.
Avanade's strength is definitely in its employees. Very hungry for technology and makes for a great environment if you are a fan of  (Microsoft) technology.
cons:
Difficult to see the relationship with Microsoft other than Avanade is restricting itself to offering solutions based around Microsoft products.
Avanade UK is far too bureaucratic for a company of its size (300 - 400 staff).
Very much about the "bottom line" (influenced by numbers).
Far too heavily influenced and linked in to Accenture - makes you wonder why they are separate companies.
Very reliant on Accenture to bring work in.
Not particularly competitive for the UK market.
People not recognised for their skills > recognition based on politics and "ticking the right boxes".
Consultants expected to work extra 20% extra to carry out expected activities and training in addition to project work.
Severely slashed training budgets result in no opportunity for training with professional training organisations and providers.
Little effort made to integrate consultants based outside of London.
London office space not accommodating for consultants.
Consultants often "body shopped" which results in them being on a project that does not match their skill set.

pros: Great people and culture, fun and energizing place to work
cons: Sometimes confusing how best to operate with Accenture

review_title: Great people, but leadership needs to reduce the focus on rapid growth
pros: The best reason to work at Avanade is the amazing people that work there.  The general consulting force is astonishingly good at what they do, and although the technical skill level has dropped slightly as we've grown, overall it is still amazingly high.  Having the opportunity to work on varied projects is great, as it can give you exposure to many industries and corporate cultures.  It is also good for the ego, as you realize that not many companies have the skill level that Avanade does.
cons: The company growth rate is insane; double digit targets every year since we started - even through the economic crash and the dot-com bubble bursting.  While this could be viewed as an impressive achievement, you should realize that the pressure to hit these targets imbues a culture of working your b**t off to get jobs done.  Although the company touts the work-life balance as a focus, it has become distinctly skewed towards the Accenture-like culture as we have grown.

review_title: Good intentions, currently on a transformation path, but a long way to go
pros:
Good projects are great, staff are engaged, and you can be supported.

Great focus on collaborative tools, and knowledge is shared across the company - people don't hoard information. 

Very flat culture, you can talk to people at all levels, and they will be respectful and friendly with you, always happy to help where they can.
cons:
No real training outside of Microsoft vouchers, and in house delivery methodology courses. If you're stuck on a bad project, you'll be there for the long haul, and although you're told you can raise issues, in practice this isn't true  - not out of malice, but hands are tied. Very much a culture of who you know, not what you know.

The short term incentive 'bonus' program is paid out based on how the company has done in sales, which realistically, most staff can't affect - though the mantra is to mention sales opportunities whenever they occur... 

There isn't much investment in future technologies - technology is trained and taught when it's already becoming a little outdated; unless Microsoft has mandated it as a standard. New technology is mainly disseminated when people donate their time for free. 

Many good staff leave quite quickly, leaving the company full of long term employees, those happy to work within bureaucracy, those in the old boys club, or those without experience of other companies.

pros: $2000 a year to buy gadgets
cons: It's all about the money

pros:
Working in the Managed Services out of Newcastle you get to work with the latest Technology with some of the brightest minds around.  Lots of opportunities to develop new skills with an endless drive for certifications.  

Avanade expects a lot from you however provides you with a reasonable salary, great training, great benefits.  

As an entry level position if you have the drive and motivation Avanade is a great place to work.  As a seasoned professional you will find it a tedious place to work.
cons:
Managed Services for Avanade is a strange affair,  being in the UK but being managed from afar.  For all the training and skills you learn limited reach to actually apply it in any sort of meaningful way.  

This ties into lack of career development as outside of the Managed Services there is limited (if any) chance to escape into other fields.  (Consulting etc)

Local Leadership expanding the truth then not delivering.  I’m not saying lying but multiple occasions would suggest otherwise.. 

Lack of consistency when dealing with HR.  UK HR is fabulous however Managed Services being overseas seem to run from two different playbooks.

pros: Good work life balance, fun community, interesting projects.
cons: Not enough emphasis put on skill development.

pros: almost everything is perfect there

Has lost its way a bit on winning and capability to deliver complex custom development work
Can be a bit political at times

pros: Avanade is a fast growing company that cares about their employees
cons: None - Avanade is a company where you can grow and learn

pros: It offers a very diverse environment
cons: The company is lagging in technology trends

job_title: Advanced Analytics Analyst in Denver, CO
pros:
Excellent, long training program. 
Eligiblility for overtime in low-level positions. 
Endless learning and growth. 
Employer-paid Microsoft certifications. 
Sponsored events like hack-a-thons and innovation summits. 
Opportunity for travel - and to earn miles and points that you get to keep. 
401k and health benefits are decent. 
Diversity of projects. 
Career advisers to act as your advocat and mentor. 
Division of regions and talent groups provide a small company feel for such a large organization. 
Plenty of resources so that you never feel “in the dark.”
cons:
Analysts are either given too little to do (or solely given “grunt work”) or they are given too much and are expected to work 50-60+ hours a week and perform consultant-level duties. There isn’t really an in-between. 

Those given too little have the opportunity to maintain work-life balance while those given heavy workloads rarely have free time outside the weekends. However, the trade-off is those who have the opportunity to go above and beyond are much more likely to see promotions and raises. 

All employees are required to obtain a certain number of microsoft certifications, which can be hard to find to time do to, especially when Microsoft isn’t used on the project. Busy analysts will find themselves focusing on the client during weekdays and Avanade requirements during weeknights and weekends. Thus, it can be very hard for analysts looking to move up to find any work-life balance.

pros: Flexible timings, WFH, on time salary,
cons: False promise about role. Team politics, bad manager

pros: Subsidized exam vouchers, great culture

job_title: Manager, Solutions Developer in Chicago, IL
pros: I cannot understand any of these reviews that deride Avanade as an employer. I have been at many consulting firms, and Avanade is the best by far. They are very transparent with their people and have really good leadership in place. The work is challenging, but not overly so. The people are great and the company culture is easily the most dynamic and engaging I have seen. We have great group activities and corporate's logistical and system support for travel, expenses, and client engagements are top-notch. I highly recommend working for Avanade. However, lazy and entitled people need not apply--they are pretty good at running your a** out the door (which the rest of us appreciate). I get job offers all the time that would pay more money, and I just honestly have no desire to ever leave such a great firm. Keep up the good work, guys!
cons: With double digit growth year over year, the performance bonuses could be a little more generous. HR policies can be difficult to understand. The number of vacation days are very slim when compared to the hours that we work. Perhaps we could be more aggressive in our rates when pursuing direct sales (vs. indirect)

pros: work life balance and salary are pretty good
cons: Sometimes you have to travel a lot

review_title: It's a .Net Programming shop, great if that's what you want to do.
pros:
It's a great place if you want to hone your development skills on the Microsoft Technology Platform. As a Microsoft Gold Partner you have good access to get your hands on and work with their latest technology.

Salary is pretty good for a programmer, benefits are decent as well. Training and conferences are available, but its about timing and who you know.
cons:
-Avanade is essentially an Accenture workforce, they run the show on projects as well as create the organizational strategy as they comprise 80 percent of our Board of Directors.
-Sales force is ineffective, so all our work comes from Accenture, which makes it tough to control your own destiny.
-Sr. Management is so focused on hitting financial goals that they overlook investment into the future. This is probably because most of management come from technical backgrounds and don't have business aptitude.
-The layoffs over the past year seem to have no pattern, so they may have been personal.
-Diversity seems to be an issue, don't see many women, blacks, or Latinos in the company as well as high level positions. Most of the workforce is white or from India.

pros: Autonomy, benefits, opportunities, salary, travel
cons: Every assignment is different. Some are more demanding than others

review_title: Great place to work if you love travel or  do not need work-life balance.
pros: Avanade is a fantastic place to work for anyone who want to be at the pinnacle of technology.  You will work with very good to great clients and work (for the most part) with the leading edge of Microsoft technologies.  This is also one of the smartest group of people I have ever worked with.  If you like to travel or want to build up frequent flier miles you can get more than you will ever use.
cons:
Work life balance is simply awful.  You are on the road 100% for years at a time.  If you are single, fresh out of school or an empty nester, then this can be ok for a bit, but it is not sustainable for most folks for a very long time.

Consulting is very sensative to economic ups and downs.  When times are good, there is plenty of perks and communications from management, but when things go pear shaped. the communication goes down hill, both in quantity and quality.

pros: There are good client opportunities
cons: It can be very cliquey

pros: Strong focus on training; fantastic initiatives for Diversity and Inclusion that other companies should follow; talented people with a fun company culture; wonderful flexible work possibilities (depending on role); And of course technology and innovation are a high priority
cons: Sometimes the flexible work options makes it hard to separate your work and personal time.  We are so enabled with our technology that almost any device can keep you working where ever you are, so sometimes you feel you have to.  A lot of people seem to check email at all hours of the day so there can be a pressure to do the same. Also, as a global company, you may have to take off-hours calls because if your team is not local.  This makes work-life balance difficult to maintain.

pros: Inclusive culture. Career development in focus, good relationship with microsoft

review_title: Great company of technologists with great opportunities for advancement.
pros:
Since we are a consulting company we are given the opportunity to work on a wide variety of projects in a wide variety of companies. In many markets we still have a relatively small workforce which means that each and every contract can be a huge opportunity for the individual consultant, the region and the company. 

We are a company of technologists. Our core workforce consists of software developers and software architects. That permeates the company's culture which is wonderful compared to some consulting companies which have downplayed the value of having a consulting force of expert technologists.
cons:
Depending on the maturity of the market in which you live, you may have to do a considerable amount of travel. This also holds true if your skill set isn't in demand in your city or region.

It can be difficult to get what some of consider the appropriate amount of recognition if you live outside of your regions primary city. This is not to say that the review process is critically flawed or anything but it sure seems to help those that live and work in the primary city. Perhaps they are just provided better opportunities due to working in a more mature market.

pros: Customer Centric and Family Oriented

review_title: Used to be great, Now clueless
pros:
- Great colleagues and exceptional technical talent
- Nice benefit perks such as the $2K "gadget budget" 
- Great individual leaders still scattered within the organization, if you're lucky enough to find one as a sponsor.
cons:
- Maniacal focus on financial targets, lacks higher mission and purpose to motivate employees
- A great place to work when we launched in 2000 and all the way through the Mitch Hill years, 2000-2007.  Now the company has lost its "mojo" and struggling to grow
- Current leadership team turned the company from an entreprenurial, growth oriented company into a cost-cutting, policy centric organization.
- Company hordes cash at the expense of employees and big, bold investments.  If your best cash management strategy is to put as much cash into the Accenture piggy bank, you've just succeeded adding 0.5 cent to their quarterly earnings.

review_title: Great company, less than market pay
pros: Great company. Great ethics overall
cons: Terrible pay. Lacking flexibility in most areas

review_title: Avanade - A great place to work and learn
job_title: Senior Infrastructure Analyst in Seattle, WA
pros:
Avanade provides an amazing environment to expand both your technical and professional skills. You are never pigeon-holed to one technology, but instead you are constantly exposed to different environments, products, and challenges, allowing you to constantly improve.

Avanade also does not limit you to what management may believe your limits are. You are constantly encouraged (and allowed) to grow your skills. You can be as customer-facing as you wish, attending meetings and interfacing with the customer one-on-one, or you can limit yourself to the technology side of things. It truly is one hundred percent under your control.

If you do not reach your goals within the ranks of Avanade, it truly is your fault. Hard work and dedication pay off with this company.
cons:
Avanade does require almost constant travel and many projects do require long hours. This is a position which requires extreme dedication.

If you have a family, you may have trouble working for Avanade unless you happen to live in an area where Avanade has multiple projects. However, every area eventually dries up and you'll find yourself back out on the road.

Most projects with Avanade see you flying out Monday morning and returning home Thursday evening, but there are some customers who insist upon a Monday through Friday schedule. These projects cause a significant strain on your work / life balance.

review_title: Riding on second stage rockets, can we break orbit or just be Good Enough?
pros: Great fiscal discipline and ability to execute, complete customer obsession in front line consultants.  We treat our people and customers with integrity and truthfulness, and I love being able to work with some of the smartest people in the technology industry.
cons: Career upside is limited as you make it into senior ranks, as the company scales more and more emphasis is placed on bottom line and operating efficiency at the expense of risk taking and innovation.  Also, the flat organization structure that placed more emphasis on collabration and group success is being replaced by a growth at all costs, you're only as good as your quota mentality, kind of sad given the company is still private and should be able to take more risks and place bigger, longer term bets

pros:
- Travel (even if its just somewhere else in state)
- Benefits (401k, health, dental, vision)
- Flexible schedule (based on client)
- People, all around are amazing individuals that you will work with. Friendly, smart, well rounded.
- Plenty of opportunities to grow. In 2 years time I worked with 20 different technology stacks in production environments.
- Growth in soft skills will be a round-the-clock thing whether you're aware of it or not. Due to working with a diverse group of people and working with many different clients.
cons:
- Too large of a company means that while the team you work with is great, the reality is you are a number to them.
- Review processes for promotion/raises is handled by a representative, your CM. If you disagree with how the review process went, there's really nothing you can do besides sing to your CM, and all they can do is shrug because the decision made at the review has been finalized.
- Some projects aren't what they make it out to be. Last project I was on was mis-communicated and baked up to be something it wasn't.

review_title: very nice company to work for
pros: tech, people, culture, technology, microsoft
cons: work hard play hard most of the time

pros: Great people and great work environment.
cons: Salaries are a bit below industry average. Some of the promotions do not feel rewarding financially

pros:
This is an IT consulting company and projects are various. Projects are long, short, big and small so everybody will find something for yourself. Of course projects differs from quality perspective. Project might be crappy for you but awesome for someone else....and it can happend in every company. What I really enjoy for all those years in this company is that: if you really, really want to achieve, change something, it is possible, of course it needs some time but there are people that will help you. I know people who were QA and become a DevOps or developer, office assistant who become QA and not only manual but great technical engineer fully working on test automation (Java/C#/JS).

If you are looking for a place with great people and mentors, place to grow, be able to make a difference (sometimes slower or faster) than Avanade is the place.
cons: Maybe I am too optimistic but I see more pros than cons, it is a subjective feeling. Definitiely there are some projects that could be more interesting or be managed better but it is always up to you what 'positive' are you getting out of even crappiest project.

job_title: Senior Front End Developer in Seattle, WA
pros:
I really enjoy working here, I am in the Digital Studio, so can't speak to other groups in the company.

I feel really supported by my coworkers - both day to day project teammates and by Studio leadership. There was one project where I didn't have much support and leadership gave me advice to help get off that project and onto a new one. This is the first job I've had where I felt if I speak up, that my concerns will be listened to.

There is a big culture of appreciation here too, for example you can give reward points to people who you think have done a good job and exchange them for gift cards. I've gotten quite a lot of furniture/electronics this way

The studio has less of a travel requirement compared to the rest of the company. If I weren't in the studio i'm not sure i would be so happy, personally though I do work with others who do seem happy.
cons:
I did spend some time on projects not using the most interesting technology, but still the problems were interesting to solve. 

Junior employees are not eligible for bonuses, which did make me feel unappreciated when I was more junior. They do a lot of the work, and often take on work well above their pay level to get promoted. they are eligible for overtime, though.

pros: Best place to work here
cons: Lack of discipline at this place

review_title: Your investment in time and effort will pay off
pros:
Great career advanement opportunities, alot of chances to meet new people, travel, learn new technologies, and new environments every project.  You are never stuck to a single cubicle depending on how often you change projects.  this is not a job that will be repetitive or lack challenges, there are always new problems that need to be solved, new people that need to be convinced, and new projects to hop onto.  
The higher ups really do keep an eye on your performance, so your hardwork will pay off and your rank will rise.  Career advancement is not based on time stayed in one position, and is very dynamic.
cons:
long work hours, social life suffers from tight project timelines.  Projects can drag on and on, and overtime is about every day if a project is due, you can bet that your weekend will be gone.  Traveling can be a bit of a drag, depending on where you go and if you enjoy the sever overhead from your home to your work.
If a project really likes you, you might get stuck there for a long long time.  Once you "specialize" in a field, the company uses you as an expert, which makes it harder for you to seek out new tech to interact with, unless done on your own time.
bench times staying at home can be less than motivating to work.

pros: Avanade has wonderful benefits. The health insurance is the best I've had in my career.
cons:
Avanade is nothing more than a body shop consulting shop.  Additionally, if you like to write code, this is not the company for you. Avanade attempts to off-shore most coding tasks. Consultants become intermediaries for the off-shore teams.
The company has no real culture either. When I started, I completed my training and was then left alone in the office for months. No one made any efforts to socialize. I often went out for lunch and had drinks with colleagues from my previous company. 
The worst part has been getting on projects. To get a decent assignment, you really need to know someone. Managers act as if they are doing you a favor to put on on their project too. And, they play favorites. More than once I nominated myself for projects only to find the position was never really open.

review_title: Not a great place for Data and Analytics and not competitive salary-wise
pros:
- You can get as many Microsoft certifications as you want
- Sometimes there are cool learning opportunities (i.e. I attended an AI training in Seattle)
cons:
- Work was uninteristing. There are very limited data science projects. The Data and Analytics projects I was on were boring simple BI/data visualization projects.
- Staffing process is unreliable. Getting staffed on a project impacts your ability to get a promotion yet there's no good way to ensure you can get staffed.
- Pay is very low. Especially in Denver. I left and got a 55% base salary increase.
- Promotion process is inflexible. I was hired at the senior analyst level. I was told it was because I was between levels and not to worry because I could be promoted in 6 months. However, it was clear to my leads from the beginning I should've been hired at a consultant level. I then wasn't able to be promoted after 6 months due to a low chargeablity rate (see staffing process). Also, even if I had been up for promotion, the process takes 3 months from start to finish. That seems unnecessarily long for a salary increase you've earned. 
- Lack of response from management. They blew me off for 3 months when I asked for a salary renegotiation. This may be due to lack of funding in the Data and Analytics talent community.

review_title: Don't do it, it's not worth!
pros: Nothing except the easy interview
cons: Honestly this company is a joke. The interview is easy, and they will probably offer anyone a job, but that's because they will let you go in a minute. So, if you have a fulltime permanent job, please do not leave it for this company. All their job is project based, and they rarely have enough project, so they are constantly hiring and letting people go, like it means nothing to them. And yes, they will lie to you and say, if there's no project you can "go on the bench and learn" that's BS, once you go on the bench, you are as good as out the door. And even if you do get another project, you must interview for the project with every other person on the bench, these projects have no clear guideline on its requirements. So, most of the time, projects are not assigned based on skills, but based on friendship. Their management clearly have no clue what they are doing and constantly mismanaged their budget. If you want a job that offers zero job security and where you will constantly be interviewing for your position, then be my guest. Trying to save you a lot of time and grief. I can't believe I left a very good secured job for this joke of a company. Lesson well learnt.

review_title: Great place to work! No, really!
pros: It's a treat to work with so many brilliant minds and inidividual persnalities.  I don't get a sense of everyone drinking the corporate "kool aid" (except the recruiters).  The innovations in technology we get to use and see put into action with our numerous customers is another good reason to come to work.  Also, everyone here understands that we are all only human afterall and cannot be treated like some machine that just pumps out the work 24/7.  They really do promote a healthy work/life balance.
cons: As a young-ish company, there have been some bad habits upper management and the execs have fallen into.  In my department, our "leader" has never gone to bat for us and he has been this way long before I ever started (9 months ago).  There has been a tendancy to let the finance department and the CFO pretty much run the company and if you are not in their favors then you are out of luck.

review_title: Great company to work for, but make sure you have good connections.
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: If you enjoy traveling, then this is the company for you.  There are many traveling opportunities.  In addition, their benefits package is good compared to others in this industry.   The people are all very smart.  Everyone is very competitive.  Avanade is tightly integrated with Accenture and Microsoft.  Many of the opportunities come directly from one of it's two parents.  There has been a lot of effort to go direct on many projects.  For most consultants, there is no need to work in an office.  To save unecessary travel cost, consultants work remotely and are travel to customer sites when they have been assigned to a project.
cons: The promotion process needs to be revamped.  Too many good people being held back. One of my biggest gripes was that there was a quota on how many folks can be promoted.  In this type of situation, you have many folks who are at "exceeds" that deserve the promotion but only a few are moved forward.  Initially, there was also talk of an IPO, however, that seems to have faded by the wayside as the economy turned.  The best way to get promoted depends on the type of project you are assigned.  High profile projects with executive visibility are the ones that appear to get the most notice and reward.

job_title: Senior Data Analyst in London, England
pros:
Amazing Company with:

Generally good Pay, Great Benefits, Amazing Culture, Incredible Opportunities.

They offer great training and progression.

Depending on the project you can work from home which is a great plus.

Wonderful office and support staff.

review_title: Great place to work, salary could be stronger.
job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: There are a lot of great, talented people working at Avanade.  I feel confident in the hiring process and most of the people who I work with I find to be good communicators and tech savvy.  In addition, Avanade puts a good deal of focus on employee training giving a set amount of training hours per year, vouchers towards certification, etc.  Combined with access to books24x7 and an MSDN developer license, it is definitely a culture where you have the ability to continually learn on the job and have access to great resources.  Also, there are a variety of different projects to work on  so you are able to constantly get exposed to new business, new technology, etc..  The work atmosphere is fairly relaxed and friendly which is also important to me.
cons: I think we have great benefits, but the overall salary compensation is a little less than some other competing businesses.  In addition, as Avanade has grown as a company they have done away with some of the small touches that I felt differentiated them from bigger companies (paid cell phone bill, $2000 a year for tech toys, etc.)

review_title: Great employer for early career stages...too political for later stages
pros: Best place to start your consulting career.  The training opportunities and mentorship are excellent - though you will probably learn more from Accenture than Avanade leadership.  You have the opportunity to own your career and pursue your interests.  Worst case, you leave in 2 years with your certifications and real world experience.  Avanade is the top Microsoft partner - great resume material.
cons:
I worked in several regions and your experience will vary greatly depending on your region/country.  As with most companies, higher levels become very political especially if you're viewed as a threat.  The culture has been negatively impacted with leaders moving between Europe, Asia and North America.  

I've read the reports regarding unethical behavior and I have witnessed this first hand.  Part of me wants to believe it's cultural differences that led a senior leader to encourage his team to break local law but that should never be an excuse.  I was encouraged to charge in more hours than I worked.  And, before any Avanade leader replies asking for more information, it was reported to the ethics hotline and no action was taken despite having multiple occurrences and witnesses.

Also, the company claims to have anti-retaliation policies.  Again, experienced this first hand, and the policies are rubbish.  Within 1 month of reporting an ethics violation I was removed from my leadership position.  But that's just a coincidence, right?  They did pay a significant severance to release them from liability.  Maybe that's a pro?

pros: Decent clients to work with.   Provided excellent technology to do your job.
cons:
Only people based out of the regional offices can get ahead.  Employees in other cities are on their own with little interaction from managers.  Company hires too many technical resources then fires them when sales production is down.  Company shifts financial failures to all employees by canceling social events and yearly bonuses without notice (found out I wasn't getting a bonus only because it was not on my paycheck when expected).  They canceled holiday and summer events because the company is doing poorly.  Total budget for both events was $5000.

For FY 2017 all employees got enrolled in the Jelly of the Month club (Movie Reference).   Yearly reviews are based on the amount of money available for raises not actual performance.  You could receive top reviews from all clients and managers,  go above and beyond getting certifications and still get an achieves\meets review score because there is not enough money in the budget to give you the raise and bonus that comes with a higher score.

review_title: You'll be okay if you know what you want and aren't afraid to ask for it
pros: Avanade is a global company so there are lots of opportunities to travel.  There are career advancement opportunities.  If you get a career manager who has been with the company for a while, they have a lot of clout and can help you advance.  Avanade has a ton of clients so each project is different - this is great if you like variety.  The pay is generous, as is the $2,000 extended benefits allowance every year to spend on things like gym memberships, travel, commuting costs, hobbies, etc.
cons: You may have to travel, even if you aren't thrilled about leaving your family.  Avanade will probably stop stack ranking employees in 2016, but the process by which employees are stack ranked is very hush-hush and depends a lot on who knows you and your work.  Your career manager is essentially your only advocate for career advancement, so you have to be careful what you share with them (i.e. don't tell them you're unhappy in your position, if that's the case).

pros:
If you want to become an expert in Microsoft Techonologies, this is (aside Microsoft) the best company to be. Parttime work  is no problem and they have a great work-life balance. They offer free access to MSDN, which is great if you want to get hold of the latest Microsoft software.
Pay is ok, you get a laptop, car and some small perks like they paying for your broadband connection etc.
cons:
Being a subsidiary of Accenture and Microsoft, it often happens that Accenture has the lead in the project. They tend to see programmers from Avanade as 'production units', write the code and write is fast.
If you are someone who just graduated and you don't want to go into programming but want to get into IT strategy, information management, business IT processes, etc., forget it. They say you first have to start on technicall jobs before you are able to say something meaningfull about business IT processes.
They seem to focused on Sharepoint implementations only lately, there is a great demand, thats true, but if all they seem to have is sharepoint then there isn't much choice is there?
Also we have seen several senior management leaving last year, heard stories that Avanade isn't the startup-like company it used to be.

review_title: Stay Away - Lowest Pay + Worst Management
pros:
glassdoor requires that I put in at least 20 words for Pros. But this company has little to no pros. You can imagine why Microsoft loves this company.
It's a technology company, that's about the only Pro I can think of.
cons:
One of the worst companies to work for.

Pay is very very low, such that it is truly not worth working for. That's because the company's revenue to number of employees ratio is very small.
There are many companies big and small in this area who pay double or more than what this company pays.
The company is very cheap and does Microsoft's bidding in terms of driving down the pay rate of developers and engineers.
Management also lies. They will lure you in, by promising to increase your pay if you show quality work. But that will never happen. The pay raises are an insult. It comes nowhere close to the rate of inflation.
If you have a family to feed. This is the last company to work for. Specially with the level of inflation we see these days.

To add insult to injury, you will also be Micromanaged. You will not be treated with respect by Management, rather they are quite rude and arrogant. 

I can write up more Cons, but I believe the two, Very Low Pay and Being Micromanaged, are enough to help those with self respect stay away from this company.

review_title: Good place to start a career, but not for the faint of heart
job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
*Great money for out-of-college hires

*LOTS of experience working in different industries, teams, markets. You will probably feel like you're drowning for the first year or so until you get the hang of it.

*Opportunities for career growth 

*If you are obsessed with all things Microsoft, this is definitely the place to be...
cons:
*Tons of pressure for changeability, which is usually out of your control. Be prepared for clients or your manager breathing down your neck and asking you to justify the hours you spent on tasks. You will always feel like you're playing defense.

*Weekly travel is not for the faint of heart - especially when projects are almost always extremely stressful. 

*Not a lot of culture due to the fact everyone travels during the week and is remote on Fridays. You will become close with people on your project but they will live across the country.

*Avanade is becoming more and more controlled in Accenture every year. You will likely be staffed on an Accenture (or even Microsoft) project, meaning if you run into any issues or problems, it's very unlikely Avanade will have any means to help you (they will try, but ultimately they don't have much say).

review_title: Workplace driven by accounting and risk management

review_title: Excellent place to work if you come in with both eyes open (wide).

Thinking like that is going to lead to toxic results. Not being a team player, not understanding team dynamics or how to collaborate well, will also lead to toxic results, professionally/career-wise. 

If you stick it out long enough, you will be able to find assignments where some pretty amazing things are happening.

Some consulting assignments can be challenging (i.e. soul-draining)

job_title: Senior Account Manager NA TA&I in Atlanta, GA
pros: No company is perfect, once you understand that its easy to see the pros and cons- Avanade is a great place to work, Culture and values are one of the best things about Avanade! In my role I work 100% virtual and that is a huge pro! People here are smart and passionate. The executive management team is accessible and easy to engage-If you are a professional and on top of your game this is a great place to grow you career. The benefits here are above average in fact they are generous, a family plan cost about $300 per-month. They ask a lot of you but what company doesn't? Mandatory training, keeps you sharp, The time flies by, very busy and never seems to be enough time.
cons: Heavy on the emails, lots of change (every 18 months major changes)  if your the type of person that doesn't like change Avanade is not the place for you! Compensation for recruiting is average or just under average by 20% however working 100% virtual makes up for that in my opinion.

pros: Avanade is a great place to work and consulting gets you exposure to many types of industries. This goes a long way with just about any employer that will come after them. The people are great! They're backed by two powerhouses so the access to training and resources is pretty good.
cons: Avanade is extremely political. Promotions are supposed to be fair, but the process is not. The bench warnings suck. You can get one as a "seasoned" employee that has been with them for a while and get the choice between begging someone to put you on a project (not for performance, but lack of work) or a severance package. Meanwhile, the people they just hired are still employed.

review_title: Big company perks with small company feel
pros:
You get to work with the biggest Global Brands on complex/meaty projects. Expanding teams like the Digital Studios, Advisory and others are gaining ground in the market and this helps Avanade attract the talent it is seeking. 

The tenure of employees her is uniquely long for this field of work and that says a lot. The key drivers that draw people her or keep them, would be flexible work schedule, the people(down to earth, humble, fun), type of work (complex), career growth (no smoke and mirrors, easy to understand), and Partners (whether your background is from the Agency world or Consulting, you get to work with some of the key players in their market).
cons: Due to the line of work with some of our teams, travel is always number one on most peoples mind when it comes to con's. It's part of the business some groups travel more then others while teams like the Digital Studios limit it. This can also be a pro though depending on what a person is seeking and the benefits of getting to travel to meet with some of our big clients.

pros: Good people, trying to do good work, but Accenture and Avanade gets in the way
cons:
- Salaries, especially for internal corporate (non-client facing consulting) roles, are far below market
- Recruiters will flat-out lie to you, don't believe anything they tell you about the work, career trajectories and realistic timelines for promo or growth opportunities, assume that the level and salary you negotiate at sign-up is where you'll be for years and annual bonuses/salary increases are microscopic
- Line managers are poorly trained and will ding the team for even the most minor of error and employees are rarely recognized even for substantial achievements - e.g., if you ask if it's ok to turn something at noon tomorrow that was originally due today and your manager says, "no problem" - expect to see "misses deadlines" in your review
- HR does nothing about the toxic and unprofessional people in the organization
- Avanade likes to massively over-engineering every process and corp is filled with people doing busywork in an effort to try to look like they're adding value

pros: Avanade tries to support flexible working with their clients. The home office is good, with coffee, etc. A lot of access to Microsoft training, healthcare, and mental health support. The people you’ll work with directly are great, although  management is confused.
cons: The company has changed a lot in the time I’ve worked here, from feeling like people want to do a good job, to focussing on internal squabbles and the short term. I have absolutely no confidence in the UK management - the new Accenture manager isn’t seen, and doesn’t seem to understand what made Avanade great. People are leaving or being fired by another name - either because of a clash with the new culture, or because the company hasn’t sold enough work. The company sells projects based on old technology, without investing in anything new. The company used to feel friendly and supportive, now it feels like Accenture. Management either isn’t giving clear examples of what they want, or they are being clear about expectations, but not enabling people to hit them.

review_title: Great company for college grads, developing skills with the Microsoft stack
pros: Excellent to start off with out of college. If you want to learn the Microsoft stack, there is no better place to learn it. They invest 80 hours a year in training and pay for your MS certifications, which is way more than you get elsewhere. Also, everyone from top to bottom seems like they care which is much different than the bigger companies. It seems like you have some level of control in your career which you won't get at other big companies either. Good benefits.
cons: They don't carry enough weight. The main issue is that they have problems closing deals. I have been assigned to multiple projects that we were supposed to sign that just fell through to another company. They only provide  a couple weeks of vacation which is pretty low. They have annual sick leave, but you never really get the opportunity to use it because you can always work from home unless you are seriously ill. Also, the teams are usually very small. That could be a good thing, but for me it just felt isolated. Otherwise, same issues as consulting in general: work life balance, limited role selection, etc.

review_title: From Startup Consulting to Low Budget Temp Agency
pros: Good budget for training. Good health care. Good people to work with. Big name clients.
cons: Salary in many places is below average. Despite what they tell you... Long hours are expected. Travel is sometimes excessive. Sales teams in certain regions are slow and there is no pipeline of new work other than scraps from the parent company Accenture. Often treated like second class citizens while on projects where Accenture is involved. Once a great startup and best place to work, is now just staff augmentation and offshore management for Accenture. Sales targets are set high so smaller work is ignored often leaving the consultants and analysts sitting on the bench waiting for work. Lofty growth goals encourage only large clients to be sought. Smaller, interesting projects are ignore because there isn't enough margin. There is little to no investment into innovation unless there is direct client benefit (aka chance for profit).

pros:
Strong technologists with heavy Microsoft enterprise experience.

Many strong customers, and the opportunity to reach into Fortune ranked corporations through their extended partnerships with Accenture and Microsoft. 

On-the-ground experiences for consultants. You will have the opportunity to represent Avanade at a customer site; you will not be in the background or be shielded. You will interact with the customer and your opinions will be valued.
cons:
Standard consulting cons apply here. It's difficult to "choose" your project and that can interfere/conflict with what your personal/professional goals are. The promotion process is hazy. You need to fit the organizational mold in order to move up. 

Accenture projects will more-than-likely dominate your docket. A common gripe among Avanade resources is that Accenture treats Avanade resources very poorly on projects. Many conflicting goals and values between the two organizations, and there's little recourse for Avanade resources to meaningfully report conflicts between Avanade & Accenture (and produce amicable results).

review_title: Great compared to many similar consulting companies.
pros:
I never get hassled about travel arrangements. I typically stay at any hotels I like within reason, fly the airlines I like and always get a decent per diem.  When you travel for a living, this is a big deal!

Management and teammates are typically high quality. The job has the potential to expose you to many elements of the IT world (given its Microsoft based). Lots of paid training time (80 hours a year) and the company also pays for all Microsoft Certifications (they pay for two tries per exam).

There is an opportunity to rise in the company quickly, with each promotion carrying 10-15% increases in pay typically.
cons: The job is ALL TRAVEL! If you don't like travelling, this job isn't for you. Some projects just stink and you can do little but gut it out and hope to be on to the next soon. Every project has a new boss, some are good, some are bad. In my experience they tend to be decent or better.

review_title: Boring, terrible, will likely be irrelevant within next 10 years
pros: Fair work life balance for most projects
cons: Recruiting is terribly misleading toward non-technical hires.   I was concerned that my lack of a technical background would put me at a disadvantage working at Avanade and the recruiter told me verbatim "that will not affect your ability to get staffed or promoted, because you're being hired to a role that doesn't require technical knowledge going in.  Anything you need to learn they will train you for."  So I take the job.  Then, there's a complete lack of opportunities for non-technical BA's in my area that don't know SQL.  They say..OK, go learn SQL to get stafffed.  Their version of 'training':  provide me with a SQL review book that ON THE FIRST PAGE actually says "you will need at least 2 years of prior direct experience with SQL in order to be able to pass the MIcrosoft certification exam, THIS BOOK ALONE IS NOT ENOUGH" so....I take the exam twice and don't pass both times.  They seem surprised by this even though I show them the book THAT THEY SUGGESTED and how it says that approach would never work.  This led to lots of time not being staffed which makes it next to impossible to get promoted.  HAd I know this, NEVER would've taken the job.

job_title: User Experience Design Intern in Chicago, IL
pros: Great people to work with, wanting you to grow in your position and to move to where you want to in a position through the company. People are friendly and always willing to try and help. If they don't know an answer to your question, they have a list of people you can turn too. They care about your opinion and want your feedback. They're branching out in UX Design, a field that could greatly aid but is still in its growing process.
cons: UX Design in general for Avanade is a fairly small department, let alone in my location. I'm finding myself unable to really speak to another UX designer in the company that is nearby, or learn from as I was hoping during my internship.

review_title: Avanade is slowly being absorbed by Accenture
job_title: Senior Consultant/Business Analyst in Seattle, WA
pros:
Opportunities for technology training 
Dedicated training time
$2000 technology benefit
Vendor discounts
3 week vacation after 2 years
Pays for Microsoft Certification
cons:
Career advancement is very limited
Cross department communication and collaboration
No strategy for Sales or Marketing
No company business standardization
Issues with pointing fingers at other departments instead of resolving issues
ITS help desk doesn't care about their customers and barely knows the products they support
Company passes to much information to their competitor and parent Accenture

pros:
Mostly smart people who are passionate about what they do. 
Still strong potential in some areas and countries with solid leadership in place.
cons:
Lost their entrepreneurial sprint as they have grown into a larger and bureaucratic enterprise.
Way too many business units are focused on cost containment.
Some business have atrocious attrition because a lack of career path growth and are out of touch with the market competitive compensation packages.
HR has clearly lost their way and the loss of key people reflect that.
Still can't work out how to make themselves a viable business in the direct space with so much reliance on Accenture for work.

review_title: Great place to master MS technology if you like travel
pros:
- Yearly "Extended Benefits" stipend for tech, learning, or services to make travel easier
- Lots of smart technologists and architects to work with
- Great place to beef up on .NET skills and certs for someone early in their career
- Fairly easy to move to other cities
- The good projects can be really good. Mission-critical internationally-deployed systems solving hard problems.
cons:
- Like any consulting gig, some of the bad projects are as bad as the good ones are good
- Like any consulting gig, you're often brought onto a project that's running late, and were described to clients who actively dislike consultants as a genius who'll solve everything.
- Over the years I was there, morphed from being its own unique company to merely a wing of Accenture. None of these changes were for the better.
- Politics often play a role in promotion, but more importantly in staffing 
- Getting on a highly-visible, successful, well-regarded project is key to promotion, but you often have no say in staffing whatsoever.

pros: Avanade has some very talented employees who are passionate technologists.  Pros:  collaborative culture, friendly environment for most part, cool technologies used internally (minus CRM), nice offices in major cities (NY, CHI, SEA), free pretzels
cons:
From a sales/bizdev perspective, majority of sales managers are former consultants, so they place  a huge emphasis on delivery backgrounds in their sales people.  If you come from a delivery background and want to pursue a career in sales, this is the place for you.  If you don't have delivery in your background and want to be in sales this most likely won't be a good fit.  Obviously there are exceptions, but my observation while there is that 75-90% of sales force are former consultants. 

From a more tactical perspective, the company has severe resouce shortage issues in some of the hotter areas, i.e. sharepoint, collaboration.  The accenture channel consumes most the talented resources for their projects and the direct channel is left to scrammble.  If the company is serious about growing direct this needs to change.

job_title: Senior Analyst, Systems Engineer in Washington, DC
pros:
1. In my experience thus far, [Avanade] management cares and is vigilant.
2. Opportunity and vertical/horizontal mobility are abundant; the former due to rapid growth and the latter due to a partiality towards change for the better.
3. Enough training and certification, both internal and external, to develop knowledge for a long time.
4. Individual performance outweighs the success/failure of a project.
5. Smart, driven, and friendly people (Accenture included).
cons:
1. Past a certain career level, it is difficult, if not impossible, to stay technical. All roads eventually lead to a shade of sales (it is a services firm). This perpetuates a two-year average lifetime from the ground-up and external hiring at higher career levels.
2. Plenty of travel, despite regional model.
3. Project availability is highly dependent on who you know, rather than placement resources or even what you know.

pros: State-of-the-art Microsoft Technologies.  Great place to learn, grow, and innovate.  Lots of training in the .NET Framework, Windows Server, and BI tools.  You have the ability to mold your career as you see fit, and can work on what interests you.  The chance to see many industries is great, finding your strengths and weaknesses and getting the opportunity to make an impact in IT.  Soft skills become more refined, and tailored to be the best professional you can be.  Great people from all backgrounds, making a community out of a company that is unlike anything else.
cons: The travel can be grueling, and not all clients are receptive to Microsoft technology.  Lots of soul-searching in hard times, and not invincible to economic conditions.  Some assignments can be difficult, and the hours are put in to make a difference, but its part of the job.  Very little negatives I can find.

job_title: Service Delivery Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Decent Pay. Some of the people are ok.
cons:
Management cares more about butts in seats than qualified staff. 

Bottom line: Its all about the Benjamin's for Avanade regardless of how you get there. If the client is unhappy but can't leave the contract so much the better. 

I worked there for 4 years. In that time I was able to get training once (and that wasn't in my field). Every request for training in my area was denied. 

Management would use vulgarity and threats on staff without recourse. 

Exercising your benefits is made problematic by unhelpful staff who seem out to hinder as much as possible.

review_title: Just finished 5+ years as a FT employee
pros: Great colleagues, internal consistency (you know where you stand, you know where to get answers you need, etc.), and solid vision with Imagine 2020 plan recently rolled out to company.  Filters down to employer branding with more streamlined and consistent messaging in FY16 (started 9/1/2015).  Serious commitment to ongoing development, esp. for IT consultants (paid training & Microsoft certifications, etc.)
cons: While Avanade is closely tied to majority owner Accenture and minority owner Microsoft (most MSFT platform technology sales by Accenture leverage Avanade personnel to implement), outside of the sales and technology, the company doesn't piggyback on and adapt best practices of the parent companies to its own operations nearly as much as it should.

job_title: Director, Product Management in Seattle, WA
pros: Fast-growing,  The traditional market has a need for their technical insights.  Decent technical acumen for the MSFT stack.
cons:
Struggling to adapt to a world focused on business outcomes and impact - creating a different value prop than the parent firm - Accenture already offers.   The vast majority of the work is "bodies" that fill technical needs created by Accenture engagements.  Not a bad thing but moots the existence of a separate firm.  
 It is questionable as to the value of the Avanade management layer in generating the little non-Accenture revenues that they do.

review_title: great place to visit but wouldn't want to live there
job_title: Senior Talent Acquisition in Atlanta, GA
pros: smart and interesting people, good benefits, leading in technology
cons: Avanade promotes work-life balance, however, your workload is so full it's difficult to get the job done in a 60 hour week! Base pay is 20% less tan market-Difficult to get promoted even with excellent reviews! Deep process to everything, lots of emails coming your way from multiple departments, above average meetings which can kill progress if you don't manage

review_title: I didn't choose consulting to sit at home with nothing to do
pros: Great training program for new hires. The people I have met are great. Some upper level people are really good about reaching out to new hires
cons: I've been working from home unstaffed since I got out of training 4 months ago, which is the total opposite of what I was told throughout the recruiting process (80% travel, working in project teams, being around people, etc). I haven't met any coworkers except at the one company event there has been, and the office is always empty. All this is especially frustrating when I moved across the country not knowing a soul, based on promises of travel and working with people...instead I've been ignored for 4 months, as have the others from my training class. No new hire should be expected to sit with no real work to do for 4 months, or anyone for that matter.

pros:
If you like being on the forefront of Microsoft technology, Avanade is a good place to be. They are the partner with Microsoft to implement their technologies in coordination with Accenture. 

Culture is more relaxed than other firms and there is a sense of entrepreneurship as it is still a young firm. 

Generally, colleagues are willing to help each other and support you in your growth. I enjoyed the relationships built and the ease of building my network.
cons:
The talent community I was a part of was quite small and there were difficulties with upper management selling work at higher levels. Therefore, promotions were more dependent on client work available at higher levels more than job performance. 

Pay is lower compared to larger and other consulting firms. 

Entrepreneurship can be a con as there is not always consistency or sophistication of process as the company grows. It also feels like ‘winging it’ is a norm in some areas. 

There are no built in mentor programs or peer support programs if you want a mentor beyond your career advisor (manager), you have to go find it through building of your network.

review_title: Stepping Stone, Not Corner Stone of a Career
pros: Good benefits for "quality of life." Given the right leadership alignment one can create opportunities for themselves within Avanade with the solid business case. Great career development model and learning/training repository.  Global company provides exposure to international and diverse project work.
cons: Work-life balance is hard to come by if you have a family or want any time off. Compensation is low to avg and they will take as much as you give, then ask for more. Like most companies of the similar size and model advancement opportunities are based on internal politics over achievements. Leadership is not consistent, some sectors have strong leaders while others have no business being in people/career management of any sort. For an "innovative" technology company, most of the innovation is externally focused leaving internal process and technology antiquated.  Since Accenture leads and owns most of the projects, Sr level/Exec advancements opportunities are hard to come by.

review_title: Watch for long hours & hard accent
job_title: Group Manager/Solutions Architect in New York, NY
pros: Depending upon the project you can learn new technologies and the processes. Get good brand names on your resume. You will love the place if you like to write status reports – lot of them.
cons:
Be ready for LONG hours. Go home/hotel after 7 PM ready for status call at 7 AM. Lot of (filler) work that does not produce any value or satisfaction. Projects get staffed by bodies that not necessarily have skills that are needed. 

Don’t be surprise if you have given a full time resource (a developer in India) and the same resource is full time resource on other project at the same time. Probably they have 48 hours in one day.

At least for folks in the field corporate organization structure is too complex to understand and meaningless for any practical purpose. I am not sure whose purpose it is serving.   

Too much pressure to maintain high billable hours and that creates a conflict resulting in unprofessional work ethics.

pros:
- Good name (Microsoft + Accenture)
- OK benefits
cons:
- No real career prospects
- Very political - if you aren't a director or above, you are just a pawn on the board; and most employees never make to director.
- Boys club
- Most of the colleagues aren't great in technology
- Interview process is from the '80s: friendly small talk instead of selecting smart people
- Your job will be to supervise the outsourced projects and try to fix what the offshore centres mess up every day
- Quantity over quality
- Nothing is cutting edge, stale corporate clients
- Strictly Microsoft technologies

review_title: Great Place to learn and grow
pros: Work is interesting and travel at times can keep the week from being monotonous. The company really shows its passion for its employees to continue learning new things. Money is given each year (max is $2k, lower for lower positions) to be spent on tech gadgets or work-life balance (including vacations).
cons: Travel can be burdensome for some, a joy for others. Pay is probably at or just below industry standard. Lots of turn-over.  You are basically Accenture's staff augmentation pool. The companies relationship with Microsoft means absolutely nothing to the company except for those who work in Seattle, the rest of the company is forced to use and sell Microsoft products, even when they are incredibly inferior.

pros: I thought many of my colleagues at Avanade were intelligent and nice people, but...
cons:
Working at Avanade was probably the worst experience in my career. The company culture that was represented to me in many, many meetings with their internal recruiter, and the position I interviewed for in multiple interviews with the person I would report to (as well as his boss and his boss's boss), were completely different on the day I joined--and not for the better. 

This is a disturbingly disjointed company: the Accenture parentage, Microsoft relationship and desire to generate business independent of Accenture are responsible for a deep and ongoing identity crisis as well as a highly dysfunctional environment. 

One additional note: Avanade is (was) highly autonomous by region; my experience dates to 2016 as a mid-level manager in the Northeast region. It is theoretically possible that other regions are different (and hopefully much better run).

job_title: Senior Consultant in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Very strong mission 
Very strong technical n talented resources 
Very good package in general
Very good management
cons:
Working for Avanade is awesome, but is not Avanade only you work for, Accenture managers and business leads will always be their over you head making life toxic and clients overwhelmed, never missing an opportunity to make untechnical n uneducated decisions 
They treat the Dev resources like and worst than working horses and will end up writing your feedback and annual reviews 
One bad Accenture manager (and they are a lot) can cause you a lot of damage,
Plus... you will end up traveling to client offices from NY to CA and sometime they will ask you to relocate 
You have th right to deny first 2 or 3 offers to work for a client out of state, but then you will feel the pressure from your leads, which will make you eventually leave, and take. Flight every weekend to far away remote location, for at least 4 month in a row

review_title: Not a place for a Career
pros:
- You can gain great consulting experience.  Avanade has many top Fortune 500 customers from which you can gain valuable customer facing consulting experience if you are fortunate enough to be staffed on the right projects.
- Benefits package is above average.  Pay is average.
- Access to cutting edge Microsoft technology
cons:
- Rampant Cronyism
- Top Heavy organization structure where most Directors are over paid and under deliver
- Frequent layoffs that often result in the best people getting cut. 
- No career model.  Most people stay until they get laid off or find a better salary elsewhere.
- Rapid growth offshore has turned company more into a body shop than a respected consultancy

review_title: Not the Same but Still Good
pros:
-Training opportunities
-Top notch accommodations when traveling
-Challenging clients
-Most people are great to work with (smart, protective of their people, etc.)
-Extended benefits ($2000 a year to spend on stuff for work/life balance items)
cons:
-Lost some of the culture that made it great.  Has gone from a somewhat startup culture to more corporate
-Recent acquisition has muddied the cultural waters.  Many "new" people don't have the same work ethic/values
-Beholden to Accenture many times
-Try to be transparent about career path but realistically it can all be thrown in the trash for things you should be doing that aren't on paper (or told to you after it was too late) 
-Consultants are expected to try and staff themselves

job_title: IT Security Consultant in Frankfurt am Main
pros: Nothing much, pros don't apply to this company
cons:
Many
1. Less pay
2. You have to bear the expenses when you travel
3. If you spend 100 euros on travel there is no guarantee that you can even get 20 euro in return from the management
4. For this 20 euro you need to get the permission or approval from your manager and then your managers manager and payroll
5. Other than your client job you have to a lot of avanade job like you have to be on bench after each project, there is no guarante of the location where you can get assigned to, you need to update your resume on many portals like you are not an employee anymore, you have to update many business applications and follow many apps on social media and promote avanade, post pics etc.,
6. You have to bear the flight costs also which is a lot of waste of money and this too is too difficult to get refund (remember the approvals)
7. Filling the expenses claiming forms is a big pain
