8. They promise to give you an amex card which is too hard to get from the amex dept. you have to struggle a lot
9. Lot of paperwork
10. Most important, ready to get fired without notice
11. No job security

review_title: The acquisition that killed a brand
pros: Avanade and their employees were well-meaning, and good at their core competency of selling and delivering large-scale Microsoft solutions. There was a clear and structured hierarchy. There was also a good sense of Avanade as a global business. Bonuses and discretionary payments were generous.
cons: A highly risk-averse and process-heavy approach meant that pre-acquisition momentum was all but killed off after about 6-9 months. There was too much emphasis on mapping pre-acquisition roles and processes to the Avanade ways, which resulted in a high degree of friction, and overall employee disatisfaction. A bit like pouring cold water on a hot engine, many cracks appeared, and a large number of people were either made redundant or left, creating a negative culture and poor workplace experience,

review_title: Hope you like Travel and being Accenture staff aug
pros:
Strong technical people, Nice extended benefit.  
The Bench.
cons:
I was only at Avanade for 9 months.  I was sold on the strategy shift towards digital and the opportunity to build that out.  I was also told the travel would be more like it was in an agency.  In the end none of that proved true.  I was specialized in mobile applications and didn't work on or see one mobile application project in the pipeline.

Avanade is VERY Microsoft centric.  Too much so in today's world.

I also wish I'd have know that Avanade was essentially Accenture's Microsoft arm.  I would never have joined the company as there's nothing about Accenture staff aug that appeals to me.

Travel is 100% no matter what they tell you.

Career opportunities are limited and driven by how much revenue you generate or save especially at the higher levels.

review_title: Top heavy, can't stop being a consultant-based business
pros: Decent pay and benefits. Good focus on inclusion. Good work/life balance with a lot of work from home positions.
cons:
VERY top-heavy. There are WAY too many people pulling down six figures whose jobs seem to boil down to vague hand-waving, being in meetings and pumping out PowerPoint decks for no real discernible purpose. 

Also, even though they've been trying to pivot to a *aaS model, they have trouble breaking free of their consultant mindset. Everything at the company revolves around consultants. I had a position of consultant and then senior consultant, despite never having consulted a day in my life: this is just how they break down their salary levels (e.g., analyst, senior analyst, consultant, senior consultant, etc.), but it influences everything in the company, where everything is seen as a project and there's not a whole lot of organization around creating sustainable products.

job_title: Senior Solutions Developer in Chicago, IL
pros: Avanade focuses on development of it's employees.  All employees are encouraged to get some amount of training in a given year.  There are a wide variety of clients out there for us and always something new to do.  They help you find the area you excel in and focus your abilities in that direction.  Every employee is assigned a career manager to help guide them through their advancement and navigate the waters of the corporate side of things.  Management, regionally at least, make an effort to get to know their employees and go out of the way to meet them.
cons: Some of the managers are not willing to listen to an employees point of view.  If negative feedback comes in from a client, their word is taken explicitly and no weight is given to the consultant's side of things.  Some career managers can be "too busy" and leave an employee to float along on their own.

review_title: If you're not a Director and have some technical talent look around, you're probably not being paid your worth.
pros: Ok little perks like the $2k/year bonus/allowance for gadets per year. My biggest issue with this is that you can't use it the way you want. E.G. no Macs.
cons: Stingy overall with compensation and no support for training. You can go here have no life, be 130% chargable and not get promoted. Just what I was looking for (NOT)! Let's be honest here Avanade is a step sister to its two parent companies (ACN and MSFT). Either of those organizations is your true destination once you arrive the sooner you realize that the better.

pros:
- Opportunities to work on medium to large scale projects. You will learn a lot and develop both technical and soft skills if you work hard at it.
- Travel which can be a good or a bad thing.
- Good exposure to Microsoft products.
- Training opportunities for improving technical and soft skills. I enjoyed flying to Seattle to attend the in person trainings. Avanade also covers the cost for taking certification exams.
- Free MSDN Subscription
- Yearly $2000 allowance to spend on things that could help with work/life balance such as Gym membership, electronic items etc.
cons:
- Greatly influenced by the parent company Accenture. Most large projects come from Accenture so sometimes you don't feel that you are directly contributing.
- Lack of focus on people and more on meeting annual sales targets. Lots of times consultants are put in staff augmentation projects where they are not able to fully utilize their skills and experience.
- Salary.

pros: Access to training and Microsoft technology is second to none. 80/year required training. I work with some incredibly smart and humble folks. Variety of projects to work on. - that you may or may not have chosen to be on.
cons: Travel can be 100%. For me it's been 100% for the past year, travelling Sunday thru late Thursday because of client commitments. Then meetings on Friday, I might get 1 1/2 days or less to spend with my family before getting back on the road. Long days, minimal options to pick projects. Always worried about layoffs from company or if/when bench clock runs out.You find out layoffs are occurring when you hear about them from the folks getting laid off then a few days later when mgt has heard everyone complain - then they issue a message about it.

review_title: Entrepreneurial Opportunities with Big Company Resources
pros: Full of smart and passionate people. Tons of chances to work on interesting projects in interesting places. For those that can advocate for themselves well there are serious career advancement opportunities, especially if you're interested in global relocation. Amazing office in Australia, Europe, Asia and South America. Company is deep into its transition from a pure technology player to a digital transformation organization. Highly collaborative and supportive organization....for the most part very egalitarian.
cons: Can be difficult to learn how to navigate your career here. You must be able and willing to advocate for yourself and proactively seek out the work and professional relationships you want. It may not happen for you in 3-6 months. Many many all-star players which can make it difficult to stand out. However if you like working around people you can learn from then this is a good place.

review_title: Learn to love SharePoint or GTFO
pros: Training is top notch.  Avanade has an internal training department that cranks out tons of internal curriculum.  And they now require consultants to have 80 hours of training a year in order to be eligible for bonus.  (I consider this a plus.  Paid study time is a good thing.)
cons:
Avanade is handicapped by their awkward relationship with Accenture and Microsoft.   It's obvious to everyone.  This has been echoes in many other reviews.

Travel is an inventible reality for their west coast-based workforce.  Be prepared to commute via plane Monday through Thursday.  If you live in New England or the Dallas/Ft. Worth then you should be fine. 

Your promotion opportunities and bonus are tied to how many billable hours you work, just like many major consulting orgs.  Some groups within Avanade (known as Service Lines) have less opportunities than others.  App Dev seems to have the hardest time finding work in sizable projects in most markets.

review_title: Great Company, just need better leadership within the UCCMS group.
pros: I have been with the company for quite some time, and found that there is a ton of opportunity to wrap your hands around. Benefits are great,  the team is great. Lots of tribal knowledge and a willingness to learn from senior resources within an given technology that is supported.
cons: Unfortunately, the current attrition rate within UCCMS group has been awful. I believe due to managements lack of leadership and communication to the group.

job_title: Senior Developer & Team Lead in Toronto, ON
pros:
Decent to good salary (85K+ for sr. consultant)
Decent training budget
cons:
- Project managers and scrum masters here have no technical background, but call the shots, not a team lead 

- High chance of getting stuck on a multi-year project and it's near impossible to get off, even after putting in 2 years.  

- Non-technical people are viewed as more important than software developers

- They don't care if the work aligns to what you want to do, they will put you on any project regardless of your desired tech stack

- Your boss won't be on the same project as you, will have no idea what you're doing day-to-day, but they still evaluate you.

- Bills client for your overtime, but you are not entitled to any of that

- Owner Accenture is held on a pedestal and can do no wrong 

- Frequently told you must put company first

- lots and lots of internal politics

- most projects are talked up to sound amazing but in reality are quite mundane

pros:
Lot of focus on learning and development, they spend huge money on learning and development.
Renumeration is good compared to other IT services companies.
Understand IT trends and try to ensure employee is aware of the same.
Global presence.
Have all kinds of projects and use all kinds of technologies.
Process driven.
Good scope for working in foreign countries.
Lot of focus/encouragement on innovation and making difference at any/all levels.
cons:
Recruitment process needs to be tightened so that poor performers don't get a job in the organisation.
Poor performers are shown the door, period. No job security.
If you join the organisation and have to report to bench then you will be lost and you will hate the company.
Supervisor/manager has too much power/authority and can make or break the career of an employee.

review_title: I love this company!  Highly recommend.
job_title: Software Engineering Senior Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros:
-Growing my career though a challenging role that is allowing me to learn a lot about Software Development, Technical Architecture, and giving me leadership opportunities
-I LOVE the culture.  The people are a lot of fun.  There are frequent outings and social activities.
-Great work-life-balance.  We are strongly encouraged from day 1 do stick with our 40 hours a week unless we are being paid overtime to work more than that.
-After my quick promotion, I believe I receive a competitive salary
-Eligible for promotion every 6 months when starting (although typically takes a year)
cons:
-Slightly less heavy-duty Software Engineering than you would find at big tech company
-Being client-facing sometimes hinders the ability to work directly with Avanade colleagues day-to-day
-Along those lines, due to the nature of consulting, you may have a role that you do not like but work through to keep up your utilization/changeability

review_title: A teenage company trying to grow but hampered by bureaucracy and its parents
pros: If you are in consulting or delivering projects at Avanade, you will find a great network of employees and management.  They have a commitment to training and clear tracks for advancement for their delivery team. Given the nature of work, they strive extremely hard to help their employees achieve a great work-life balance.  Benefits are amazing.  Personal time off is respected and there is a great sense of teamwork.
cons: If you are in sales, you will encounter a company trying to develop a brand identity and with limited account relationships.  A seasoned sales person joining Avanade will encounter a management team that has never managed a world-class sales organization and with very little leverage to make things happen.  Compensation plans are not aligned and if you are selling on Avanade paper, you will encounter channel conflicts with the parent company, Accenture.

pros: Training is good, benefits (ie: 401k and healthcare) are great
cons: Everything else about this company is awful.  Leadership is selfish and focused on their scorecards, there's little concern for building a great place to work.  Sales team can't spend any money to make money, there's little to no celebration.  This company is officially a joke now.  Very sad as they were once great to work for.  Keep raising prices and maintaining your highly priced overhead and you'll continue to drive yourself into the ground.  The companies sales outlook is grim, growth is lagging and management continues to lay off regularly.  RUN away people - don't look at this company.  The hire one day and lay off the next because chargeability is a management metric (understandable) but your lack of ability to be competitively priced has created a vicious cycle of HIRE AND FIRE based on your unpredictable sales demand.

review_title: Excellent place to start of in the world of consulting..
pros: Microsoft powerhouse - if you want to learn about the latest Microsoft technologies, this is the place.  There are also lots of training available, both internally and externally.  You get to work with a great group of people, a great group of people that knows how to have fun and enjoy life.  Via different projects and events, you can meet many people and improve your networking.  Senior management is very easy to approach.
cons: Even though the company tries hard to promote a work/life balance, the balance is beginning to tip towards the work side.  Pay in general is less than other consulting shops.  This feels more of a transition company, where you come in, build up your skills, meet people.  After that, you'll be thinking, "OK I'm done here - where next?"

pros:
Top 5 reasons to consider working here:
1) The collaboration is amazing.  
2) There is full communication across all levels within the company (Analyst to Director).
3)  Intellectual knowledge is freely shared, which makes learning a joy.
4) Your worth is measured by your product knowledge - rather than your title.
5) The training opportunities are exceptional.  Certifications, classes, professional development - all inclusive.
cons:
Top 3 reasons to look elsewhere:
1) Accenture owns Avanade and the work cultures are very different.  One rough Accenture project (and there's plenty of those) and you'll be on LInkedIn looking for your next opportunity.
2) An overly collaborative environment unfortunately sacrifices any chance for true leadership development.  There are plenty of Managers, but exceptionally few leaders here.  Accenture is not looking for leaders with their hired help.
3) The bonuses/pay-raises are insulting.

pros: Free training and certifications. You could travel often for work and can accumulate miles, hotel and car rental points for free personal travel.
cons: No work-life balance. Your top priority should always be the client, even before your personal life. Management only cares about keeping both Accenture and the client happy all the time. Even if the client is asking for deliverables outside scope or shortens the deadlines management always says yes. You are forced to meet the deadlines even if the clients wants to change requirements at the middle of the sprint. It is not a place where your ideas and contributions are appreciated. There is no culture, it is just a software factory.

review_title: Lots of training and bear with lot of blames
job_title: Solutions Consultant in New York, NY
pros:
- You will get lot of Microsoft related training, with two weeks of paid annual training time
- Great for new graduates to absorb new techs and growth
- You will get travel cash back points from hotel, rental car or airlines (not from company itself) if you like travel
cons:
- Salary is below market average
- You are obligate to go with any client if company send you to, you may end up with bad/terrible client that layout you off and you will have a bad review
- Annual managers review is a mystery spot, any of your project manger can jump up and rumbles something then your year review is dead for promotion
-  You will be ready for political fights in certain clients or even within your team, group, bear with blame and prepare your resume for next

pros: Over the past twelve years I've had the opportunity to grow my career at Avanade.  While market conditions have sometimes dictated how, I have always been able to influence the trajectory and velocity of my career development in roles ranging from consulting, to project management, to industry, to sales, to sales management, to practice management.  Avanade as a consultancy isn't for every customer or every employee but it is generally very good at what is set up to do, enterprise scale systems integration and outsourcing on the Microsoft platform.  The people at Avanade are at the top of their game and the company is commited to developing its talent.
cons: Avanade is a large organization made larger by the close ties to its parent, Accenture.  Sometimes it can feel like you're an employee number rather than a person.

review_title: Really smart people, but lots of time away from home.
job_title: Solutions Developer II in Chicago, IL
pros: Working with many of the brightest technologist in the business is the biggest benefit to working at Avanade.  Peer support is high, and there is a LOT of communication despite the large distances between many of the consultants.  There is no concept of "minimum years at position" before a promotion, so in theory the best and brightest can bubble up to the top as soon as they're ready.
cons:
Travel is the #1 drawback to working for a global consulting company, such as Avanade.  Consultants must be prepared to spend long hours in the air and lots of time away from their homes.

There isn't a lot of transparency into the salary structure, and reviews are only conducted once a year.  This can lead to large time gaps between opportunities for promotion and advancement.  Also, the bonus program is pretty poultry.

pros: Quality training.  Great delivery methodology.  Nice events - they truly make an effort to connect consultants.  Get to work with very competent team members.
cons:
Archaic annual review process.  The process is horrible and it is all about who knows who.  They actually get everyone in a room for a level above candidates being stack-ranked and talk about each candidate.  Keep in mind 90% of the people in the room don't know the candidates.  

May not be staffed on a company project, but instead be staffed on an Accenture project where Avanade employees are not treated very well.  

Very much a good ole boy network that I thought was gone from the workplace until joining Avanade.

pros:
- Competitive Salary

- Consulting lifestyle is cool. You get to switch projects and teams every so often and it keeps things interesting

- Nice office in a great downtown location near Go Train 

- Lunch and learns, company events etc. 

- Good work/life balance. Not too many long hours, but depends on your project.
cons:
- Confusing and concerning on-boarding process. Didn't know what was going on, so I felt alone in the dark. But it was fine as the months went on. 

- Your first project might be a boring, low-value, low-visibility project with minimal coding. But then again, you might be assigned to a project which is using awesome machine learning algorithms to cook hot dogs faster, with an AngularJS front end. Bit of a gamble here, but the long term looks like there will be more wins than loses.

review_title: Sounds great on paper, but fails on most engagements
pros: Lots of travel, good assuming you like it.  Average pay and benefits.  Great fringe benefits like airline miles.  You are usually stuck in the trenches with likeminded coworkers, so you build team camaraderie and make friends quickly.
cons: The mentoring/management system is convoluted - you get a random boss who doesn't know you, doesn't care about you, and doesn't spend any time with you.  Semiannual reviews are like meetings of a secret society, and you have no chance of going anywhere if you don't know someone on the inside.  Upper management is largely inaccessible.  Avanade is attached to their partner Accenture at the hip, even though Accenture engagements are universally horrible and have high failure rates - but they refuse to cultivate independent engagements.  Their other partner, Microsoft, is treated like a competitor - expect no help from them.

review_title: Great Place to start, but watch out!
job_title: Software Engineering Analyst in Redmond, WA
pros: This is a great place to start if you are directly out of school. There is a formal training that takes about a month that is very hands on and involved. More relaxed than other companies.
cons: You can easily get placed on project that you are unhappy with. As a developer, they had me use a no-code (advertised as a developer free) platform to create applications. I have brought up my discomfort, and my feeling of being underutilized. After 3 projects, each with a promise that it'll be my last time using that platform I decided to look elsewhere. Since there was no actual development going on, I had to brush up on my coding, developing, and engineering skills and go elsewhere. Got a nice pay bump in the process too.

job_title: Solutions Developer in New York, NY
pros:
Avanade is a great place to work to develop your technical ability. You are frequently challenged, doing meaningful work for frequently demanding clients. 

As a former manager put it, "by the time Avanade is called in to a project, the sh*t has typically hit the fan. A project is flagging and needs to be put back on course or some solution needs to be delivered yesterday. So by definition, our work is demanding"
cons: As a decentralized consulting firm, its easy to get lost in the siberian outpost of "client site". Its very easy to feel like you work for the client over Avanade and it takes effort to maintain a good strong connection to the mothership particularly on long running projects.

review_title: Avanade Provides Opportunity, Networking and Fertile Ground for Dedicated Minds
pros: Avanade provides a supportive environment for learning, developing and networking among some of the most talented and creative professionals in the IT Consulting industry.  A wide variety of learning programs, peer training and on-the-job learnings provide Avanade employees the opportunity to expand their knowledge base and further contribute to the organizational growth.  The emphasis on developing a career path and fine tuning leadership/management capabilities assures that employees are given the tools to rise to the next level, provided they work hard, contribute regularly  and display the aptitude to take the Avanade vision personally as part of their career path and goal to grow with the company.
cons: Due to the large quantity of work and dedication involved to projects from leadership down to field level support, the work/life balance can become an issue if not continually checked and regulated.

review_title: Good company if you are a PRECISE fit for what they do
job_title: Business Development Director in Irvine, CA
pros: Great, smart people who are passionate.  Cool things to work on.  Feels like the company has a strategy and momentum
cons: The company is somewhat conflicted between strategic goals and what needs to happen in short term to close business.  This conflict creates a lot of tension.  Also, they say they want to be independent of Accenture (one of two parents, the other is Microsoft) but most efforts tend to favor projects coming from Accenture and there is little willingness to invest in new client development.

review_title: Good place to start, italian Management lacks vision.Company incapable of acquiring  projects without Accenture's help
pros: You have a chance to work with very diverse technologies in the Enterprise spectrum.
cons:
Career advances are sabotaged by an over-complicated and bureaucratized evaluation mechanism  that at the end of the day produces a ton-worth of paper that nobody cares to read. Promotion are instead given on a  retention-tentative base rather than on  a meritocratic one.
A senior employee stated on his "goal for next year" form  that he wished his soccer team won the championship. He carried on this joke for five years and none of his managers nor the guys from hr questioned this statement. This only proves that the evaluation of employees' performance is performed on subjective, obscure and very questionable criteria.

pros: Avanade has a great ignition program for students right out of college. They provide a ton of training during your first month here and really prepare you for your first project. Because you will be working on different projects with different clients you will learn alot and will have to learn quickly. If you are a self learner with alot of drive and love to work on different projects while also including some traveling this is definitely the company for you!
cons: As with any consulting company sometimes you will be on the bench. The bench can be a good time for you to update your resume,  online portfolio, LinkedIn etc. While also taking this time to self learn some new design tools, and get yourself involved in studio events. However, sometimes if on the bench over a long period of time this can seem like your ready for some kind of project work. It would be nice if Avanade could provide their studio with more workshop events and internal projects.

review_title: Opportunity to make a difference and grow as an employee.
pros: Great opportunity to build up your resume with the latest and greatest Microsoft technologies.  Since Avanade is a child company of Accenture and Microsoft you get chances to work on some extremely well planned projects which will make a measurable difference in a clients day-to-day operations.  Avanade provides clear expectations for what they expect from you as employee and provides clear guidance for personal career growth.  They provide extensive resources for training and certification and strongly recommend employees utilize them.  Even if the start-up like work environment isn't for you, you will leave Avanade with current Microsoft Certifications and the experience you need to take the next step in your career.
cons: Salaries are slightly lower than other companies in the area with similar job responsibilities.

review_title: A great company with a few big problems
pros: Avanade is a great company filled with smart, hard working people.  It’s also a company that knows how to build team comradely and have fun.  In addition, in spite of the bellyaching to the contrary, Avanade’s compensates its technical employees well above market rates (at least in the U.S.).
cons: Avanade’s big problem is that they are largely a one trick pony.  The bulk of their business is application development on the .NET platform.  Their infrastructure business has languished over the years.  Repeated attempts to diversify their portfolio of services have been less than successful, largely because of how they are organized and how management is compensated.

review_title: One of the best IT consulting companies out there!
pros: There is always something new to work on. You will have the opportunity to rotate through many different industries and technologies. Your peers will always encourage you to grow, learn, and challenge each other. Development teams that I have worked in the past are always enthusiastic and demonstrate a passion for the technology they are working on. The company as a whole stresses training and development in all aspects of software consulting, not just the technical side. The extended benefits that all the service line consultants receive are one of the best contested privileges in the IT world.
cons: Some of the assignments are remote work but not all, and this sometimes requires you to be an efficient time manager. You will be required to travel for other assignments for extended periods of time, and while I personally enjoyed traveling, there were some peers that would opt out of project assignments that would require traveling.

pros: Infusion has gone through a big transition recently to Avanade.  The way the integration was handled reflects highly on the company.   There was plenty of communication around changes, and an opportunity to have one on one conversations if needed and most recently a survey to gather feedback and make improvements. The work here is great with employees being exposed to emerging technologies and variety of work in different locations. The environment allows for rich collaboration, ability to learn from some of the smartest people in the industry and time to have fun!
cons: At times it takes a while to switch projects and align professional goals to the work that is being done but there is effort to do so through goal setting and clear communication with management.  It's important not to loose sight of employees professional development plans to further grow their careers in areas that they are interested in.

pros: Avanade has 2 huge parents and has some of the smartest technologists working to solve global clients needs.
cons:
Travel at Avanade is a huge part of the role. Client facing Consultants can be away from home for up to 80% of the time and whilst on different projects can be away from home Monday - Thursday. Our Consultants have meals, travel and accommodation paid for, 2 devices and their own credit card to help manage additional expenses. 

For many consultants travel isn’t a negative aspect of the role, It’s a major positive and gives every employee the ability for change, progression and technical challenge on a constant basis.

For those not looking to travel or have a strong work/life balance perhaps consulting as a line of work isn't the best option. However, if you are looking for a role with variety and change maybe consultancy work is for you.

pros: It was great several years ago before Accenture essentially took it over. The pros then were great culture, ability to work on remote projects from home (limited to no travel), good benefits, great project work, delivering great value to customers through development expertise and feeling like Avanade was its own company with separate values and culture. Not being Accenture was what made it great.
cons: Below average pay and a slow downward spiral once the Accenture integration began. By the time I left, it seemed like everything was being developed offshore, quality didn't matter anymore and everything was about profit. You basically were forced into travelling full time or you wouldn't get on a project and risked sitting on the bench too long and getting laid off.

pros:
Great community to work with. There is lots of training, most of whose costs are covered by the company. Also there are social activities where you can bring friends and family.
In terms of career, each year you set up goals and if achieved, there is a chance to get promoted to the next level and/or salary increase.
cons:
Not only you need to achieve your goals, or be an excellent professional at the client or clients you have worked during a year, but you need to stand out by participating in other activities like internal/external workshops.

if you get recognition, assuming that your project is big or the client is big, you have better chance to get promoted and having said that will raise the bar for other employees on the same level as you.
In my first year, I got really good feedback, happy clients, presented new technology and yet no salary increase nor promoted to next level.

pros:
Exposure to cool things coming out of Micosoft
The average, billable employee is pretty smart and good to work with
cons:
Severly hampered by both the "Not Invented Here" syndrome and the "No done at Accenture" syndrome
Senior Management has little ability to lead anything, they just follow what the parent cmpany does or says to do regardless of the fact that Avanade is very different size wise, project wise and culturally
Organizationally it is very confussed, local (Country) management tends to do what it wants and more importnatly not do what it does not want.  Corporate oversight is very weak and shows in various audits.
The recent reorg in the US makes no sense to anyone who works with customers.

job_title: Senior Sales Leader in Houston, TX
pros:
Superior consulting acumen and technical talent spanning the Microsoft ecosystem which allows our people to build integration skills well-beyond just the Microsoft platform.
Avanade is a JV of Accenture (top industry consulting expertise in the world) and Microsoft (top enterprise technology software provider in the world) and therefore is able to bring value to our clients at scale.
Avanade's annual workplace survey continues to trend positively given the company's commitment to our people.
cons: Everyone doesn't always get the opportunity to work on cutting-edge projects but many do.  Also, being part of Avanade's consulting workforce may result in travel-based assignments (something which is fine with some consulting resources, but is challenging at time for others).

pros: There is a great support system to help you figure out how to be a consultant, and you get to work on a very large variety of projects. They pretty much throw you on wherever they need to and expect you to learn how to do it. They will also provide a huge amount of time for your own personal training, and will pay for you to attain certifications.
cons: Almost all projects are far too easy for someone who went to school for computer science or some related major. I spend a third of my time coding at best, and some of that is during training. The other time has been spent doing various "business" activities or using tools to do IT sort of work. Almost always using five to ten year old tech and not practicing valuable skills

pros:
Avanade is finally taking steps into the strategy & business change arena. This will let Avanade capitalize on work out side of the traditional Microsoft SI bucket the company has played in. The company is fantastically supportive of BD's willing to go and hunt for new work & to focus outside of ambulance chasing Accenture & Microsoft. 

The company has a very strong community and support network in place with Leadership being 100% focussed on growing the business naturally. 

I have never experience a company so willing to support a driven BD. This is a company for entreprenurs and self-starters. Those expecting to be handheld and coddled should look elsewhere.
cons:
Archaic, Kafkaesque process. 

Avanade is trying to become a sales organisation, however leadership needs to do more to cultivate a sales culture

review_title: If you have the will, there's a way at Avanade. Great Opportunities
pros: Avanade has great opportunties available to someone who is willing to go after them. Make a good business case on why or what you want with your career and you're likely to get it. Avanade offer tons of training to help with both career growth, financial growth, and personal growth. They are a people company. The experience and career at Avanade is what you make it, they provide the tools to be successful, you just have to make time to use them.
cons: Even though there's a good career tracking system in place, sometimes politics get in the way of advancement within certain verticals of the company.  While training is key to Avanade, it's difficut to take time away from deliverables to leverage all that's available and meet minimum training requirements.

pros:
This is, in my opinion, a great company to work for. I have worked for many companies and seen just how bad some places are. Avanade is certainly one of the best I have ever experienced!
Yes - you will work damned hard.
Yes - you will need to be flexible and gear up when needed.
Yes - you will be stretched in terms of your skills and what is expected.
But, if you're not afraid of hard work, a challenge or being pushed out of your comfort zone, then Avanade is a great company.
cons: There is still a great culture at Avanade - although rapid expansion is driving the acquisition of people and it is a challenge to ensure that they have the right mindset or work ethic that makes a place a great one to work. Senior management are truly outstanding.

review_title: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly.
pros: I am surrounded by very intelligent and talented coworkers. People are hired to do very specialized tasks and they are normally the best of the best.
cons:
This is a very political organization. One way to get ahead is to rub shoulders with the right people and many times, these employees get promotions. Some employees do not care about teamwork and just focus on their tasks.

Personal performance is a key factor in one's promotion. This sometimes causes some employees to manipulate the situation by keeping key information from his/her team members to purposely make themselves look good. These said employees will backstab other coworkers and position themselves into their ideal position within the company.

review_title: Fast paced, hi-tech, business growing well, great people and culture, operates in the Microsoft/Accenture ecosystems
pros: Great people and culture - much more switched on and less political than most companies. Work will vary project by project but you can create your own opportunities by specializing in new and hot areas and by getting more involved in supporting sales to open or expand customers relationships. Benefits are excellent especially extended benefits (gadget fund). Future seems bright and mood is quite upbeat.
cons: Travel and being stuck on a tough project even though there is now more focus on local work in the new US org model. Have to learn to protect the personal time. Sometimes customers are not aware or willing to try the new Microsoft technologies which could be better than what they are using. Finding time to train on all the new releases.

review_title: Great Place to launch your Technology Career
job_title: Global Service Delivery Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Great Organization to work for, good leadership and mentoring platform.   Leading edge of MS technologies and Microsoft Stack.   Great collaboration and team atmosphere and support system.
cons: Middle management systems in place are shaky and often politics tend to hinder actual progress of individuals and lack ownership of accountability on many different aspects.  Very limited software and technology offerings being smaller brother to Accenture and Microsoft, where they are always offering MS Stack which is good, but also bad and limits options for client solutions.   Cohesive teamwork ethic often not praised enough or valued enough for efforts

review_title: Employees are not treated as persons, but as disposable instruments
pros: Highly qualified professionals at mid and entry levels across the organization, use of collaboration technologies, exposure to leading edge Microsoft technologies.
cons: Terrible work-life balance, extremely sycophantic corporate culture where telling executives what they want to hear is encouraged, and flattery and alliances are more effective in furthering somebody's career than actual performance and knowledge.

review_title: Know what you want from your career
pros: At Avanade you have the ability to be exposed to the entire spectrum of Microsoft technologies, often before they hit the Alpha or Beta release stage. For example, we had teams working on the innovative MS Surface product for a solution expo before the product was officially announced to the public! There is also a great focus on certification and education. Also, Avanade will help you get what you want out of your career as long as YOU drive it and make opportunities for yourself.
cons: Engagements are heavily based in technology, and projects often lose sight of the bigger strategic business impacts of their project efforts. Engagement management must continually balance technology against the strategic business drivers for their projects, and Avanade's senior leadership occasionally doesn't do a very good job of communicating this to customers (which is something that Accenture does remarkably well).

pros: Good place for college grads to learn a specialty.
cons: Subsidiary of Accenture - and more and more dependent on the parent to generate revenue, and which also makes it hard for Avanade to get out from under the parent's shadow. Also ~20% owned by Microsoft, but no special favors there. There is some great talent that comes through, but management doesn't do a great job of recognizing talent when the have it. The internal roles, such as within IT and operations are fine, but the consulting roles are too specialized and complicate efficient delivery of solutions.

pros:
- interesting projects coming via Accenture and Microsoft partner network
- working with smart people
cons:
-  once you get assigned to a project you become more an employee of client than Avanade - you get disconnected from everything that is going on 
- you usually have a career advisor who you never met before, who sets regular calls with  you but there is anything he/she can do for your career development
- there is no ongoing discussion with consultants about state of your assignment at current client 
a) your service its extended for another year without letting you know
b) you don't know if next month you will still be there
- nobody asks you / propose you other interesting projects in your talent community

pros: Super flexible and such diversity of clients and projects make it a great company and a great role. On top of that there's a real, genuine push for career progression and for training.
cons: It's a culture of play hard, work hard. If you want to get ahead you quite simply have to invest a lot of your own / personal time for training and other activities.  If you aren't London based then you're expected to get to the offices yourself, under your own cost just to "Get your face known" - which apparently is required for promotion.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Training and no ongoing development left to your own devices,
cons:
No drive to succeed 
No motivation and encouragement 
No ongoing training support
Lack of full development needs based on individual basis

review_title: The most awful experience I ever had
pros: Very central and well-connected location
cons:
I can describe Avanade as a bunch of skillless people who cover each other's back to keep their jobs in this 'hard for business time'. 

And here's a few reasons why:
- Awful onboarding: they all stuck in some old systems and you never can have real human support, everyone is hiding under an e-mail address. 
- Terrible management and irresponsible hiring: they are not able to provide that kind of work they hired you for and will throw on you different unrelated to your role tasks juts to keep you busy, and after this will put a lot of pressure on you regarding your 'career goals' and how are you going to achieve them. 
- 'Playing politics' is the main key to success there - probably a common symptom for a corporation but highly visible here.
- They don't have any integrity and don't respect the values they state for: if people matter for Avanade, how comes that those people don't have at least a normal place to eat or, sometimes, even to work.

review_title: A decent place if you don't mind working long hours for mediocre pay
pros:
Very technology driven.  They really support developers and their technical growth.  I learned a lot in the 12 months I was there.  There were some cool benefits, including a technical spending package of $2000/year on anything techie.  Although this was back in 2005 so I'm not sure if they still have this.

They paid for my Microsoft Certification in full.  I was really grateful for that.
cons:
I worked in the Denver office from 2004-2005.  It was very frustrating being there.  The pay was very substandard and the senior management played a "buddy" system with their church friends.  They seemed to be the only ones that moved up.

As far as the corporation as a whole, I don't think it was as bad, but the Denver office really handled things poorly.  It was very political.

review_title: My experience with Avanade has provided me with a rich experience with different Microsoft technologies and industries.
pros:
- Work with a lot of smart and talented people.
- Get access to an msdn subscription and have full access to Microsoft software.
- Possibility of traveling all over the United States to work on different projects with different clients.
- A lot of free training opportunities to learn about Microsoft technologies and earn certifications.
- If on a traveling project, work from home on Fridays.
cons:
- Expected 80% travel.
- Possibly working long hours (50 - 70 hours per week).
- High risk job environment if there are no available projects to staff you on.
- Not as much interaction with co-workers from your area. Difficult to build the sense of community and culture among peers with the constant travel.

pros: Access to Lots of Training,  flexible schedule, good benefits, some (but rare) very good, knowledgeable people.
cons: I have been working for many years now and I continually get disrespected by my colleagues. They try to give me 10% of the information, expecting 200% of the work that is due yesterday. They also don’t include their technologists when selling and solutioning. How does this work in a technology company? They are too reactive and not proactive. I’ve been raising my concerns to managers and leadership, they just sweep it under the rug. I feel not listened to. They talk about transparency and communications, yet they forgot it is a two-way street. The project environment structure is toxic, with your technologists at the bottom on the ladder. You end up doing the work of non-technical people because they prefer to a mange than to actually do the work.

pros: Great place to learn the skills pertinent to your job field if you are just starting off. The hours are long at times, but its a great way to absorb everything. People in the company are generally helpful in all aspects, ready to spill their brains, as opposed to other companies where people don't like to share for the sake of job security. The perks also vary depending on your Project Manager, but if you're lucky you might get a really awesome PM and enjoy yourself while traveling. There is also "bench" time where if you are not on a project, you pretty much get to hang out at home playing xbox and still get paid.
cons: Long hours. First 10 hours are 1/2 pay, then the rest are 1.5x pay. This doesn't apply to higher level people though, only peons. =)

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Seattle, WA
pros: I joined right after college - put me in a great position to learn a lot, gain quite a bit of experience quickly, and (when I voiced my interest) go into leadership (Project management) type roles.
cons:
I felt my starting salary out of college was low 54700, when glassdoor reflected higher, I tried to negotiate and was shot down. I was told I would make the difference in OT, but all my projects told me OT was not allowed.
The culture changes completely depending on the account/project/client you are on. Sometimes you might be lucky, sometimes not. I was on a client where I felt the Avanade side was a boys club and management protects the people who make them money - even if they shouldn't be with the company.

review_title: Strong, promising. High exposure to international experiences
pros:
Strong capabilities in both traditional and innovative system integration and managed services.

Unique relationship with with a top-tier global system integrator, Accenture: coordinated still quite independent, cooperating but with a clear differentiating focus: deep, dedicated Microsoft platform capabilities.

Good access to global experts through a structure of communities of practice and reasonably informal culture that accepts and encourages reaching out outside hierarchies to peers and seniors worldwide. 
This generates significant international opportunities for individual at many different seniority level, and strong international exposure for managers and directors.

Strong exchange of best practices across independent country-level businesses.
cons: Similar to most large, global system integrators: it's difficult to differentiate from each other and to compete with nimbler local businesses with less structured processes and a more flexible cost structure.

review_title: Great company for proactive people where you can learn new things each day.
pros:
- Very collaborative environment
- Some very challenging projects and clients
- You can have an impact here (at the office life and what's happening in your project)
- A lot of trainings opportunities (classes, certifications, lunch and learns, conferences, inner team collaboration like codereviews or pair-programming)
- New technologies used on a daily basis (to name a few: AI, Angular5, Docker, microservices...)
- Work-life balance
cons: I have the feeling that we've lost some autonomy after integration with Avanade.  Our new PM friends sometimes focus more on process itself than project's purpose and those who make it happen. Hopefully we'll adjust more to each other soon.

pros:
-VERY smart people - top notch consultants
-notion of stablity is a huge plus- Avanade has been in business over 9 years, long relative to other Microsoft Gold-Certified Partners
-great benefits 
-unsurpassed credentials for work and assets on Microsoft platform
- high customer satisfaction rankings support the above
cons:
All of the pros make Avanade seem a no-brainer.  But the downsides - 
-HR has an emphasis on career planning - but this is rarely realized in reality, in reality this is a top-heavy organization providing little opportunity for advancement
-clubby atmosphere inhibits career advancement - this seems most pronounced for virtual employees
-regrettable lack of sales-savvy - not an 'everyone sells' culture
-heavy on process, often for process' sake

review_title: A decent consulting firm with a niche from the big 4
pros: Avanade has a Good working environment, great colleagues, fair benefits and is owned by Accenture, so moving around is easy.  I found the work environment was relaxed, focusing on getting your work done, from wherever and whenever possible.  Office hours were mandatory only by the fact it was the most efficient way to work and face time is important. Working from home though was no big deal.
cons: Long hours, pay is a little below that of another firm such as Accenture.  Sometimes the tasks can get a little too specialized. it's also a consulting firm, so expect to be exempt from a lot of overtime pay, but be "on-call" quite a bit.  Sunday afternoon calls with Asia (their morning) were very routine for me.

review_title: Great Place, Great Environment, Great People
pros: Great culture, smart people, excellent benefits, awesome training, no manager (yes, has concept of Career Manager who helps you grow within the company professionally, they are more like mentors/friends and do care for people whom they mentor). As this is consulting firm, managers are more project based. Over all great people to work with. No serious complains. You work hard/smart and eventually get rewarded.
cons: You might spend periods on bench (without project... but not a big issue) as Avanade is very picky about the projects and do not sign up client by lowering rates just to win (i guess that's Pro actually). Might end up doing lots of travelling (this is pre-condition before joining usually for most positions, unless otherwise clearly stated). Based on project, may end up working long hours (who doesn't now a days)

pros: If you work in the Service Line, you will be exposed to everything under the sun. Fast-paced environment in that line. If you work on an ATS project, expect to be there until you decide to move to Service Line, or you outgrow the contract's financial constraints. As with everyone else, getting paid to train is a huge benefit.
cons: Our CM never really had much communication with upper management, which left a lot of the people on the contract in limbo. Career advancement is slow. There wasn't a happy median for communication, either there was too much, or not enough.

pros: Project team, flexibility in traveling and opportunities to work with some great clients. I’ve built some valuable skills and confidence due to my project work.
cons: The company had somewhat succeeded in killing my morale. I have been passed over for promos on really silly technicality or baseless reasons. In my time here, all clients and PMs have went out their way to give and sent excellent reviews on my behalf but I have realized all of that do not matter. I appreciate the opportunity here and wish they would encourage people who go above and beyond for clients and promote on merit to encourage people. I have come to the conclusion that promotions are just based on time and if you have the patience they will eventually hand you one even if underserving.

review_title: If your X Accenture you will have no issues...
pros: Health benefits are decent
cons: 2 weeks vac time to start, they say they grow, want their people to take training - only if your selected to attend the training. Most of the training are online webinars. Very high schoolish - if upper mgmt likes you then your slotted for a project. If they don't then your on the bench and let go. If you take a stretch role there is no forgiveness if you make an error. They claim its the people that help however everyone is trying to get the same roles or they are over worked and can't help. X Accenture people always get slotted for projects. Its who you know. MS projects in Seattle your treated poorly - no one there knows or care that MS also has ownership in Avanade.

review_title: Great place, if you don't mind the travel
pros: The people here are for the most part incredible. They are very smart, well rounded & very approachable. I've met so many great individuals here, and have made more than a few friends. Lots of emphasis is placed on training, with good (not always great) resources at your disposal. There's no question in my mind that if you jump in with both feet, you will get great experience here. You will be challenged to excel towards excellence, and be given the guidance/feedback to grow.
cons: Some people love regular traveling, though I view it as a negative. I do enjoy occasional traveling, but not fond of the long-term traveling engagements. Also, the career management here, while it has many strengths in terms of the people involved, I believe suffers from an overall process viewpoint (mainly the system used to track project feedback and growth).

review_title: Sucking up to the right people is rewarded above talent
pros: If you're prepared to kiss the right backsides and turn up to pointless events to get involved in the "Avanade ecosystem" your level of competence is irrelevant.
cons:
As above.

If you find yourself on the wrong side of management you'll be pushed to one side and left to rot until you decide to leave for the sake of your career. 

Avanade creates an environment where consultants are forced to compete against each other for roles, opportunities, and career progression.  This is how they push staff into working incredible hours as their approach is that someone will be prepared to do this so everyone will have to do this or be left behind.

review_title: Avanade is a great place to grow skills, but it may come at some costs, such as traveling situations.
pros: The employee benefits, as well as the training model they have setup to help you constantly be updating and honing your skills. They also offer a vast amount of free software through the parent relationship with Microsoft. There seems to be quite an emphasis people being their assets which is refreshing to show that they seem to genuinely care about their employees, and don't just see them as a number.
cons: Hit or miss with travel, if you want to travel sometimes it seems like there is no work traveling, and if you want to stay local, there is no local work. Sometimes project might not be the latest and greatest technology you might want to work with.

pros: Avanade really does care about it's people - yes they care about making money and doing well as a business but of course they should! And when the business does well, we see more investment in people, benefits, bonus, initiatives. There really is a drive to create actions from engagement surveys and it's become the norm to have committees of people (blended levels and roles) working to address some of the people issues.
cons: It's a hardworking culture - Average is high performing, if you're looking for a laid back and lazy role then it's probably not for you - you get out what you put in.

review_title: Great company, almost completely true meritocracy
pros: Corporate community genuinely interested in your growth and development; multiple resources to help you in all aspects of your life; generous benefits across a range of services (healthcare, mobile phone, etc); corporate discounts at tons of vendors (cars, phones, gyms, etc).
cons: Most positions require 50%+ of travel; for example, I fly 4 hours to the client site Sunday night or Monday morning, then return late Thursday.

job_title: Senior Consultant Solution Developer in Seattle, WA
pros: I worked with some really great people. Great training opportunities.
cons: Expect to work 50+ hours a week as a base not including travel time. Once all is said and done, this job will be your life. If you're early in your career and want to be immersed in your career this is a great job for you. If you are experienced and want to grow in other areas of your life, this job is not for you. I've also seen relationships and marriages severely strained by the demands of projects and travel.

pros:
1. The internal and external training opportunities are great.  We are second to only one other company in this area.
2. Smart people and things get done.  There's not a lot of red tape.  
3. People are empowered and communication is good.
4.  We've been named by consulting magazine a best company to work for
cons:
1. The Work/Life balance could be a lot better here.  A minimum of 55 hours/week is expected of us and most put in much more than that.  
2. Compensation could be better
3. The way we are rated against each other to determine advancement
4.  Our attrition numbers are down but it could still get a lot better.

pros: I have been at Avanade for almost two years and I’m seeing a real focus on employees experience lately.  They have recently brought back  an in person training for new Managers and Directors, every new Canadian hire now goes to Chicago for a 4 day onboarding, they do an employee survey twice a year and communicate results and new initiatives, they recently bumped the vacation for junior employees to 3 weeks to start and they seem to be investing in their Career Advisors. The Toronto office has a good vibe.  There are lots of events happening like Toast Masters, Game Nights, Charity Events and Lunch and Learns. Communication is also pretty good.
cons: Avanade is a big company and b/c of that processes can be tedious.  They are currently working on re-vamping the outdated performance management system.

review_title: Challening but Avanade needs to invest more in their employees
pros: Opportunity to work for large customers on highly complex and challenging projects.
cons: Lack of real training (currently about 1k per person per year) only self study training available.  No training on how to be a consultant, long hours and no bonuses for consultants.  IBM has an incentive program based on individual performance and company success.  In fact this will be the first company I've worked for where I don't participate in any type of incentive program.

pros:
Paid to learn .Net and meet new and interesting people who are dedicated to their jobs and inspire others to be the same way.

Clear goal oriented promotion system.
cons:
Learning to work a position that is not in my job description, meaning the position was a mix of business analyst and developer and if too heavily business analyst oriented, it creates a feeling of deception to the client as if I am supposed to be someone I am not.

While there is work locally that teams can contribute to, and learn more than book experience, they would keep people on then bench instead. The cost of putting a developer onto the team may be out their hands in a travel situation but for local instances I don't understand it.

pros: Some really smart people in the development teams.  Clean restrooms.  Great technology in conference rooms.
cons: The company mis-leads its customers, they talk one thing and deliver something else, sweeping real issues under the carpet. Management are all 'in the boys club' and look after themselves. Personal agendas are rife within management in the IT area - they'll stop at nothing to better their own careers, and I mean nothing - dishonesty seems to be a quality they aspire to. Manipulation is a daily goal.  I've never worked for an organization that shows such a lack of respect to its staff.  High turnover rate - not surprising, the smart people leave. Forget it if you are a woman looking to get into a senior management position within a technology area - it's boys only.  I've witnessed senior management make racist , homophobic and sexist comments. Avoid this place.

job_title: Senior Consultant, Data Engineering in Chicago, IL
pros:
Avanade is currently the leading firm when it comes to Data and AI for Microsoft and Azure. I have the opportunities to work on the latest and greatest. Cloud Data-warehousing, Databricks, Spark, AI, etc. I've worked for boutique firms and know most of them out there. Avanade is simply the best.

Internal IP - Technical tools, methodologies, templates, best practices, etc. Avanade provides you with the best tools in the world for succeeding on team engagements.

Travel - Opportunities to travel the world or stay in region.

Events - Multiple employee events per month with team.

Growth - Opportunities for growth are unmatched.
cons: - Company or Talent Community outings could be improved.

review_title: Really sad sales culture, old boys culture, hiring women to cover
pros: If you are looking for a job where you will work with great people and have tons of support, Avanade is a pretty good place.
cons: If youre in sales, stay clear of this mess.  You'll always play 2nd fiddle to Accenture and only management can close big deals--they will take your business, raise your target and provide little to no support.  Oh, and they love VP's--tons of tons of upper management who I heard regularly say, "do these people actually know how little we do here?"  Lazy tech leaders who think only of themselves.  They've tried to hire women is sales to offset the boys culture but the women end up behaving like the good old boys culture.  Stay clear!

pros: Work with smart people and cutting edge technologies. They provide experiences via the wide set of roles in different projects which means that work is never stale. The support from management and ability to learn are 2nd to none and there are numerous initiatives within the company to encourage boundary pushing ideas. The benefits are great too.
cons: Client expectations are proportional to the bill rate clients are charged, this means a lot is expected in a very short time so work life balance is not great, I have worked on projects where compulsory 12 hour days were expected for months on end. This is almost always when we are working as a subcontractor for another large Consulting firms projects (~75% of time).

review_title: Avanade is a great place to work for a short time
pros: Avanade will stretch and challenge you. The work that Clients hire Avanade for are generally very tough delivery situations or new and unfamiliar technology. The people that Avanade hires are mostly high functioning and high achievers. Most people will tell you that the best thing about Avanade is the people you work with.
cons: As a consultant at Avanade, you will have high pressure to be chargeable. Often times, this may mean doing undesirable work to meet short term chargeability goals. Also, most of the work heavily leverages offshore teams. For some, this is a major burden and detracts from the work. Finally, work life balance is often difficult to achieve with frequent travel and difficult delivery schedules.

pros: Great training available whether internal or external for many different technologies and soft skills. Great starting company for those who love travel and want to be client facing team members, or for those who prefer working local, there's also local options to mitigate the amount of travel.  Many opportunities arise to take control of one's career and learn and use the latest technologies.
cons: Sometimes the person mentoring oneself is not on the same project as oneself so they cannot see first hand their pupil's day to day work.  This disconnect can sometimes be bad especially when the mentor is asked to vouch for their pupil.

job_title: Infrastructure Consultant in New York, NY
pros: I like working at Avanade because of the ridiculous amount of room for growth. Wherever you turn, there are learning opportunities for you. The learning opportunities are limitless. Because of the nature of the work, we are require to be experts as we roll onto our projects. We are pushed to learn as much as you can. Also, aside the the growth opportunities, people are just truly nice. I've had good experiences with everyone I've encountered. Even as a new joiner, I had people go out of their way to help me. I don't take that for granted. Lastly, they have a great structure for onboarding, so I personally wasn't lost when I joined.
cons: The only con, is that if there is a low demand for consultants it can take a while to get on a project. It all depends on client needs.

review_title: They pretend to pay you with learning and career aspirations
pros: The best part of Avanade is learning and the colleagues. Regarding learning, you can move through a lot of companies and learn their processes and methods. Avanade is a joint venture of Microsoft so you get all the licenses for free. With regards to the colleagues, hungry makes very good friends...
cons: The salary was simply a catastrophe. 12K EUR a year in 2004. Performance are measured by comparing you to your colleagues. The rate I got from my customer was the highest but my manager told me "look, all the people are having very good ratings so I will give you a 'meet expectations'".

review_title: Great company, but hard to have a social life.
pros: Avanade is a good company with good fortune 100 type clients.  I enjoyed the recognition of working for a big playing in the consulting field.  It also helped to have Accenture as a parent company.  They were able to throw tons of work over the wall.  I never feared the company would run out of growth opportunities.
cons: When working at Avanade you have to do a bunch of traveling.  Basically you trade in your social life.  When I worked at Avanade I spent about 90% of my time working at the client's site.  That mean 8-12 hours of travel a week plus 40 hours of billable time.

review_title: Great place to start your career
pros: Great place to work if you are just starting your career. You can pick up both technology and business skills while working for a lot of diverse clients, if you are open to travel.
cons: As the company is trying to grow, focus is on sales but not enough on people. Company is teaming up with Accenture more these days, which affects the company culture. Rank and file consultants can feel treated like pawns by senior management. Career model has gone through several rounds of changes recently. But it all felt like 'nominal' changes, not much real stuff there. With those so-called metrics in place, management has short-term behavior because the metrics are done annually.

pros:
Exposure to consulting with extremely large organisations
Great stepping stone for graduates & those starting a consulting career
Compensation for non-graduates is exceptional
cons:
Feels like an IBM club.
Over the top social programs that focus almost entirely on Women in IT and limit resources for other social causes that employees are legitimately interested in.
Accenture work ethic; grind you to the bone. 
Will abuse your expertise by forcing you to travel to execute the same projects year on year for different customers, pigeon holing your career growth
Graduates are held back by unwritten rules for when they can be promoted etc which strains career mentoring processes. Graduates paid at bottom end of their "level"

review_title: Solid accelerator but with burnout short sited management
job_title: Senior User Experience Designer in Seattle, WA
pros: The number of projects I've gotten to work across industries has been amazing and the companies them selves have been large Fortune 100. It's been really wonderful to get such exposure in such a short period of time
cons: Avanade is consulting company owned by Accenture and the shortsighted DNA runs deep. The organization has a single goal of making as much money as it can in any way it can. As lower and mid level employees this puts allot of pressure on you to achieve changeability metrics with vary little reward coming to those employees.

pros:
We have a very flat organization structure.  I feel comfortable sending an email or talking to anybody in the organization, from the CEO to entry-level employees.  Our leadership group is very approachable.

Compensation is very competitive.  I feel as though I am well compensated.  I can't speak for the benefits in countries outside the U.S., but the benefits in the U.S. are great.  Ask about flexible benefits when you interview; they're a really cool feature!

Excellent availability of the latest technology.  You won't be working on computers that are obsolete, outdated operating systems, etc.  

Very flexible work environment, and very casual.  You can come to work in jeans or a suit, and no one will care.
cons: I can't think of any.

pros:
- Lots of opportunities to grow
- Nice shirts, bags and other merchandise
- Some of the departments get new technologies to play with
- Lunch-n-learns where you can get an idea of what other teams do
- office space is pretty nice
- salaries not very competitive
cons:
- Horrible knowledge transfer process
- Departments are separated from each other
- Managers create chaos by shuffling people around trying to cover all the gaps, one week here, two days there and so on. 
- People who are locked into one project don't have much opportunity to grow

pros:
As part of the digital studio, we get cool perks and awesome people to work with:
- competitive salary
- snacks in the office, including avocadoes, Pocky, protein bars, etc
- down-to-earth management that are open to discussion and impromptu conversations
- very talented employees
- lots of social gatherings (board game night, video game night, miscellaneous employee-driven events)
- kombucha on tap and alcohol some evenings
- interesting projects and healthy work culture
- frequently catered free breakfast / lunch
cons:
- can be on the bench for an extended period of time, depending on sales pipeline
- lots of new initiatives that take time to grow
- may be assigned on-site to a project that's far away
- may not be as great a work place for non-digital studio employees

review_title: Hard work, great training good experiences
pros: The chance to work with Great people who are leaders in their field. Fantastic training for softskills (not so good on hard was my experience!) very demanding in MCPD requirements makes it very Hard Work to balance with family and utilization targets.
cons: Probably a lot better place to work now the consulting industry has picked up again. Would probably work for them again. I (personally) would need to be stronger about my demands and expectations as an employee. Particularly around work-life-balance. I am a stronger person, and I think Avanade will push you around if you let them.

review_title: Wonderful working environment | Challenging assignments always
pros:
Avanade offers one of the best working environments in the Industry worldwide.  Employees are allowed to work from home or anywhere else to manage their working hours to suit their comfort (min 8 hours in a day). 
All projects are quite challenging and a new learning opportunity. 
Indefinite amount of resources to and connections with Accenture and Microsoft also within Avanade worldwide. Free to join any ongoing training from Microsoft or Avanade / Accenture 
Promotes latest technologies and focuses on upcoming trends, invests in research and POC's for new technologies. 
Practices SCRUM.
cons: Employees are given tough goals to keep up-to date with the emerging new technologies and market trends.  It often involves 3-4 certifications in an year.

pros:
Good technical people
Good training
Backing of 2 industry giants
cons:
Avanade is not a company it is a body shop for Accenture
Accenture look down on Avanade and tell all Avanade people what to do
Avanade leadership have no ambition other than to survive and are total yes men to Accenture
Their leadership have made a lot of money from being yes men to Accenture and they think that makes them good. Promotion is done behind closed doors and is rarely based on merit but more on secret deals and meeting boardroom quotas

job_title: Group Manager in New York, NY
pros: I was with the company for more than five years.  It's a great firm with lots of smart people.  In the last few years, the company underwent some management changes.  It is also trying to re-define its image.  As the company gets largers, it has become more corporate, so the culture has changed.  However, the fundamentals are still there.
cons: Chargeability pressure, changing its company identity, losing some great people, over-correction on its corporate focus.

review_title: Anything for the client at the expense of the employees
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: Good salary,  good people, emphasis on continued learning.  Great technology.
cons:
There is no work life balance.   I was on a project where I was working 14+ hours a day,  7 days a week,  for a month.  I got a "day off" when I got sick.   My supervisor had me tell her when I was going to church so she knew not to expect me online (I worked from home).  The bottom line is all that matters.  Work was outsourced to India for the sake of cost.   When quality suffered,  the US team had to make up for it.   I had daily anxiety attacks.   HR and management knew that my health was at risk and they did nothing until my physician intervened and put me on medical leave. 

Getting laid off was the best thing for me.

review_title: Great learning, but you'll work hard
pros: You'll see great projects, you'll learn a lot (on the job). You can move roles easily if you're willing to pick up the skills. There's a good focus on new technologies, and the culture /people you work with directly are brilliant and friendly.
cons: For a relatively small company, there is a significant amount of internal politics, mainly around inane things. This seems to be down to ongoing organisational change, but is improving over time. The new leadership seem to have a handle on this. There isn't much in the way of flexible working, so be prepared to work long hours, and carve out time to refresh yourself.

pros: Avanade  leader's are easy to approach and always willing discuss any issues or suggestions for improvement.  Suggestions are not only listened to but considered and good ideas will be implemented quickly. They welcome people who take initiative  and will provide the support that you need to make it happen.
cons: While Avanade Ottawa is a small office with a friendly atmosphere, it is closely tied to Accenture and many projects are done in partnership. Culture differences between the small company and a  very large one  can a make it a challenge for empoyees to adapt and assimilate to the demands of both.

review_title: A company that truly invests in their employees
pros:
Avanade has an excellent culture! It has a flat company structure, provides opportunities to collaborate with employee globally who are at different levels in the organisation. The leadership team are approachable and recognise achievement within the business and are appreciative of their efforts. They ensure that they are rewarding their employees and often trialling new initiatives to improve the culture and teaming internally. 

Avanade make a big investment in their people on a yearly basis, customer facing consultants get up to 80 hours of paid training a year including Microsoft certifications. Their investment in their people is amazing, and I've not seen it matched at any other company I have worked it. 

I highly recommend this company and would definitely refer a friend to work here.
cons: Improvement in some systems is needed

pros: There is a serious desire to update and change the business strategy.  People here are smart and earnest.  There are a lot of folks who have been here since the very beginning, mixed with newbies, which leads to interesting conversations.  The proclaimed focus on customer seems to be sincere.
cons: Bit of an identity crisis: is this an Accenture shop?  A Microsoft shop?  How do we build our own culture and identify? Decision-making has to run up the chain, sometimes unnecessarily complicating that process.

pros: Great place to learn and advance. If you are a guy.
cons: UCCMS Department has issues with sexism and gender discrimination.  Training and promotions are often give out on a basis of favoritism and gender.  Complaints about sexism are not taken seriously by management.  Women are often are given leas critical tasks.  Men are often given assistance with work, while women are ignored and treated as incompetent. When mistakes are made, men are treated like its no big deal, while as a woman even a small error is treated with harsh criticism.   Guys are given more challenging and higher profile work.  Male employees often talk down to the female coworkers.

pros: You know you're one of the best if you're brought on. Many smart people with great ideas and supportive of your career. Enthusiasm abound and folks are passionate about their work. Leadership is trying their best to move at the speed of the market.
